data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
os.android: Disables use of SD card as home directory.

Partially fixes #40532.
Partially fixes #42942.

The path "/mnt/sdcard" is not guaranteed to be accessible and even less
writable from libqi on Android, therefore it is a bad candidate for the
home directory. There does not seem to be another accessible candidate
from libqi without having the Android context of the application that
embeds libqi, so we make the call fail (with an exception).

If users need to get some path on Android, they must either use the
Android API or the NDK.

Also rewrites the error message of both `home` and `gethostname`
to be clearer.

Change-Id: I7175162c8e120a817ba14d9279343b476cb47c07
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/218
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: gerrit <gerrit@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.os: Disables file access for machine-id retrieval on Android.

Fixes #42942.
Fixes #42899.
Fixes #40532.

This commit replaces any file access when trying to retrieve a
machine-id on Android, by the generation of a random id that persists
for the duration of the process. This is therefore not a real machine-id
but nonetheless closer to some than was the case before this commit,
since the function would always fail to access the file and would
therefore return a different id on each call.

It also rewrites the `getMachineId` function implementation to remove
the use of an `initialized` boolean and a mutex, and instead use a
`static` constant which is guaranteed to be initialized exactly once
during the process lifetime.

Change-Id: I40844872ff24aee38e3d8263bdb7b6e575caad19
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/1491
Reviewed-by: gerrit <gerrit@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Sébastien Barthélémy
data.message:
qi.os: Uses systemd's machine-id when available. (#44701)

Libqi processes running on the same machine but with different
`userWritableConfPath` could not communicate through localhost.

This patch fixes this problem on platforms where systemd is available.
On those platforms, qi-messaging's machine-id is now common to all users
of the system, and independent from the user home directory: the
~/.config/qimessaging/machine_id file won't be read nor created anymore.

Change-Id: Ie33c0e6fa2ad8ef3770d8a71056bc09f4f83231c

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.application: Fixes high CPU consumption due to high-frequency `run` loop.

The loop in the `Application::run` function was causing an excessive CPU
consumption because of its short sleep duration.

This patch removes this loop and uses the blocking `run` function of the
`io_service` object instead. Doing this forces us to put the
`io_service` in a global static object.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.signal: Removes generation of regularity operations on `ResetBounceEventCallbackOnSubscribersContinuous`.

This type is in fact not `Regular` as:

- at least one of its fields has a non-`Regular` type (`AnyWeakObject`)

- it does not follow a value semantics anyway (non-independence of copies
  notably)

Moreover, even if not actually called, the presence of regularity operations
causes build failures on some platforms, as these operations are (abusively)
instantiated.

Change-Id: I7583bba5ff5da0b6560ef2843d92dfe3396be046
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/1285
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

Reviewed-by: gerrit <gerrit@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: gerrit <gerrit@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.sha1: Removes unneeded Boost.Uuid sha1 header.

This header was left by mistake, the whole goal of the current implementation is
to *not* use it, as the sha1 implementation in Boost.Uuid:

1) is defined in a "detail" namespace

2) doesn't correctly handle endianness, producing digests that differ from those
of standard tools, e.g. `openssl sha1` and `sha1sum`.

Change-Id: I9f96aff5e5b6cc5c63e3bd2839c3fd2f4a0168d3
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/1273

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.Buffer: Forwards `reserve`'s reallocation failure to the caller (46231) (spec:/sbre/framework/2021/b)

When asked to reserve memory, a `Buffer` tries to reallocate its memory to fit
the given size. The potential failure of this reallocation was silently ignored
by `reserve`, typically leading to buffer overrun.

Any reallocation failure now leads to a null pointer being returned to the
caller of `reserve`.

Change-Id: I3bcf748aa399607310d7c3c9e29fa4194360470a
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/1171
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: gerrit <gerrit@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: gerrit <gerrit@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.message:
qi.tests: Makes path concatenation portable in `Application` tests.

Path were concatenated as strings, explicitly specifying the path separator
('/'). This is not portable as separator differs according to OS. `qi::Path`
already abstracts this out and is now used instead of string concatenation.

Change-Id: I08d5c1e1e4f4919e6d7cf9fb167c4e7e38e0c49a

Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.tests: Fixes a floating conversion in functional tests.

VS2015 didn't accept constructing a `std::vector<float>` from double literal
values (e.g. `std::vector<float>{2.5, 3.8}` caused a compilation error).
Consequently, `float` is replaced by `double` as this does not impact test
semantics.

Change-Id: I9b63693e45381e7005551aa2c01e73f2fc663f55
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/1205
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Vincent Lartaud
data.message:
libqi.application: fixes 'qi::Application' creation crash on protected path.

Fixes #45680

By default, 'qi::Application' tries to check if the path exists, but part of it
might be protected on some platforms, in which case a SIGABORT is triggered
because of an uncatched exception.

We made sure that each time an error occurs on path construction, including
access errors, an empty path is returned so we can track those errors and
avoid crashes.

Change-Id: I761bed51899cd9385a33968857a7abdb1bbc3723
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/126
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: vincent.lartaud <vincent.lartaud@external.softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Vincent Lartaud
data.message:
libqi.application: fix stop handler inclusion in the signal sets list on run.

Signal sets were created using the global handler list insted of the local one.
But the local one added stop handler that had not been browsed to create its
signal sets.

This implied that the stop handler would never be called and the program would
not terminate correctly when a SIGTERM or a SIGINT is catched.

The solution is to browse the local list that has been completed instead of the
global one.

Change-Id: Ia2df4cd21c7b4dba94d660b1b4e9214b8482b535
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/1103

data.author: Vincent Lartaud
data.message:
qi.application: Sets and removes signal handlers during 'run' lifetime. #46111

There was a possible crash on application exit, because a callback that
occurred during the process exit tried to execute code using a program that
could be already closed.

Before this fix, handlers were removed during the process exit, causing a crash
when they were called outside of the library's lifetime.

The solution implemented by this fix is to manage handlers only in the run, to
make sure that every handler is removed before the program exits.  With this
fix, it's impossible that a handler still tries to access a program that has
already been closed.

Change-Id: If5466c73c201c08fccb246b510c0e92b5415d03f
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/977

We now track `RemoteObject`'s lifetime by inheriting from
`boost::enable_shared_from_this` instead of embedding a `Trackable`
member.

This avoids the deadlock that could occur in the destructor of
`RemoteObject` when we would wait for the tracked to finish from inside
a tracked callback.

data.message:
test.ka.uri.parsing: Changes a gtest expectation to calm asan down.

Replaces `EXPECT_THAT` by `EXPECT_EQ`.

Although the use of `EXPECT_THAT` was a priori valid (i.e. to compare values),
and the test did pass, for some reason the call made asan detect a
stack-buffer-overflow. Using `EXPECT_EQ` calms asan down and is more homogeneous
with other tests.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.type: Allows properties to have asynchronous accessors.

Might fix #44998.

This patch changes the accessors inside `PropertyImpl` into
asynchronous accessors that return futures. This allows clients to
construct properties directly with these asynchronous accessors,
avoiding the need, for instance, to wait in these accessors on some
other asynchronous function which result is needed to get or set the
value of the property.

The API of property types was already composed of member functions that
returned futures, so no change was introduced there. A set of new
constructors was added to property types.

This change enables us to correct some of the code of `ProxyProperty`
that previously needed to block on asynchronous remote access to a
property, that used to impose some non required thread blocking in
client code.

Change-Id: I43148d2f458b371ef482fba0885714b6ce452e4e

build: Fixes warnings on Linux.

Fixes #44746.

This patch fixes warnings found in libqi on Linux on the configurations
listed below.
It does not fix warnings from external headers (such as boost) though.

Tested configurations:
======================
  - desktop - toolchain feed 'linux64-1604'
    * debug / release
      - GCC v5.5.0 from Ubuntu 16.04 default development packages.
      - GCC v7.4.0
      - GCC v8.3.0
      - GCC v9.1.0
  - android:
    * release:
      - ARM    - toolchain feed 'android-arm'
      - ARM64  - toolchain feed 'android-arm64'
      - x86    - toolchain feed 'android-x86_64'
      - x86_64 - toolchain feed 'android-x86'
  - atom (pepper) - toolchain feed 'linux64-atom'

Warnings found:
===============

-Wpragmas:
----------
warning: unknown option after '#pragma GCC diagnostic' kind.

-Wparentheses:
--------------
warning: unnecessary parentheses in declaration of ‘T’.

-Wnoexcept-type:
----------------
warning: mangled name for ‘T’ will change in C++17 because the exception
specification is part of a function type.

-Wdeprecated-declarations:
--------------------------
warning: ‘T’ is deprecated.
Often T is `std::auto_ptr<U>`.

-Wmismatched-tags:
------------------
warning: 'tuple_size' defined as a struct template here but previously
declared as a class template.

-Wmissing-field-initializers:
-----------------------------
warning: missing initializer for member 'T'.

-Wunneeded-internal-declarations:
---------------------------------
warning: function 'f' is not needed and will not be emitted.

-Wunused-function:
------------------
warning: unused function 'T'.

-Wundefined-var-template:
-------------------------
warning: instantiation of variable 'T' required here, but no definition is available.

-Wsubobject-linkage:
--------------------
warning: ‘T’ has a field ‘m’ whose type uses the anonymous namespace.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.messaging: Fixes deadlock between `BoundObject` and `ObjectHost`.

There is a circular dependency between `ObjectHost` and `BoundObject`.

When a `BoundObject` object receives a `terminate` message, it tries to
remove itself from its owner (an `ObjectHost` object). This sequence
locks, in order, a mutex in the `BoundObject` that protects its internal
data and then a mutex in `ObjectHost` that protects the object/socket
bindings.

So the thread T1 that executes this sequence locks two mutexes M1 then
M2.

When a socket disconnects from a libqi TCP server, the `Server`
object tries to remove all bound objects related to this socket from the
service bound objects it contains. This sequence locks in order the mutex
in each of service bound objects as `ObjectHost` that protects the
object/socket bindings and then a mutex in each of the `BoundObject`
objects that protects its internal data.

The thread T2 that executes this sequence locks two mutexes M2 then
M1.

╔════╗         ╔════╗
║ T1 ║         ║ T2 ║
╚════╝         ╚════╝
  ▼              ▼
  |              |
  locks M1       |
  ▼              locks M2
  |              ▼
  blocks on M2   |
  ▼              blocks on M1
  |              ▼
threads block one another = deadlock

Obviously this can cause deadlocks if operations are not executed
carefully and if mutexes are not released early enough. Therefore we need
to be careful when modifying methods of this class.

This patch makes sure that bindings in `ObjectHost` are destroyed
outside of the lock that protects the bindings storage.

Change-Id: I5f3ea73968e829170cabeb488ef5c5109c283c34
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/96217
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.messaging: Tracks `BoundObject` lifetime from its `weak_ptr`.

`BoundObject` now inherits from `boost::enable_shared_from_this` and we
rely on that to track its lifetime, instead of a `Trackable` member.

This avoids the deadlock that could occur in the destructor of
`BoundObject` when we would wait for the tracked to finish from inside
a tracked callback.

As a result, the code that was added to handle this deadlock becomes
irrelevant, and is therefore removed.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.messaging: Ensures client retrocompatibility. (spec:/sbre/framework/2020/a) (#45842)

Outline
=======

For the handshake to succeed, the intersection between server cipherlist and
client one must be non-empty. Before this patch, the client and the server
shared the same cipherlist. Now, this cipherlist is dissociated into a server
one and a client one. The server one is unmodified, but the client one is
extended by including more compatible ciphers. These extra ciphers' role is to
make the cipherlists' intersection non-empty with old servers, i.e. old servers
will choose one of them.

The security of new servers is not affected by this extension, as these extra
ciphers are not part of their cipherlist, so they cannot be chosen.

The security of old servers is not affected either, as they don't specify any
cipherlist, which results in choosing one of the extra ciphers.

Detail
======

"old servers" are those using qi-framework 1.6.3 and below (corresponding for
instance to naoqi 2.9.1.122 and below).

Client's cipherlist is extended with the following TLS ciphers:

TLS cipher suite name           | OpenSSL equivalent name
------------------------------- | -----------------------
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256 | AES128-SHA256
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA256 | AES256-SHA256
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 | AES128-GCM-SHA256
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 | AES256-GCM-SHA384

The following matrix represents connection outcomes ("pre-TLS1.2" means before
the TLS1.2 patch 78e8cf7, "TLS1.2" means incorporating the TLS1.2 patch 78e8cf7,
"TLS1.2-alt" means incorporating the TLS1.2 patch 78e8cf7, *and* this patch):

client \ server   | pre-TLS1.2  | TLS1.2      | TLS1.2-alt
----------------- | ----------- | ----------- | -----------
pre-TLS1.2        | OK          | KO          | KO
TLS1.2            | KO[^1]      | OK          | OK
TLS1.2-alt        | OK[^2]      | OK          | OK

[^1]: KO for servers running up to qi 1.6.3 (naoqi 2.9.1.122), OK above (qi
1.6.4 and above, corresponding to naoqi 2.9.2.50 and above)

[^2]: Affected by this patch: success is now possible because server chooses one
of the extra ciphers.

See [](spec:a/retrocompatibility) for more info.

Change-Id: Idaf22912e3400da9dbecefe37cbac6e9e97aaa8f
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/187
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.messaging: Forbids client TLS downgrade (spec:/sbre/framework/2020/a) (#45843)

To connect to a server through "tcps" (i.e. SSL/TLS), libqi 1.8.0 and 1.8.1
clients can accept to downgrade to SSL, if required by the server. The
motivation is retrocompatibility with older robots, but it appears this
downgrade is unnecessary.

This optional downgrade behavior has not been introduced by libqi 1.8.0 and
1.8.1, as they only raise the client "maximum" protocol from SSLv2/3 to TLS1.2.
Also, as this potential downgrade is entirely decided by the server, any NAOqi
gateway requiring TLS1.x cannot downgrade to SSL and will communicate with a
libqi 1.8.0 and 1.8.1 client with TLS1.x.

As a result, libqi 1.8.0 and 1.8.1 do not strictly weaken security, but they do
not make it as good as possible. Indeed, preventing client downgrade to TLS1.1,
i.e. making it use TLS 1.2 only, is enough for the targeted retrocompatibility.

A malicious server could still expose a libqi client 1.8.0 or 1.8.1 to a
"Man-in-the-Middle TLS Protocol Downgrade
Attack":https://www.praetorian.com/blog/man-in-the-middle-tls-ssl-protocol-downgrade-attack?edition=2019
justifying this patch.

Change-Id: I3a814dcb3fccd594eb5c83f9a5bdd126d496f133
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit2.aldebaran.lan/209
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

critical.

data.message:
qi.messaging: Makes `ServiceDirectoryProxy` implementation less blocking.

There were a few call to Future.value() in the implementation functions
of the service directory proxy. This patch replaces them with
continuations.

This made the MirroringResult structure useless because errors can
now directly be put in the futures returned by the functions. Instead
we have a MaybeMirroredId that is simply an optional to a integer.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.parse: Adds fundamental parsers and combinators. (spec:/sbre/framework/2020/d)

Concepts
========

ParseResult
-----------
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
concept ParseResult(R) =
     Functor(R)
  && With Regular A, InputIterator I:
       EmptyMutable(R<A>)
    && iter: R<A> -> I
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
A parse result contains an iterator and optionally a value.

Parser
------
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
concept Parser(P) =
     Functor(P)
  && With Regular A, InputIterator I, ParseResult R:
       Function<R<A> (I, I)>(P<A>)
    && (forall pa in P<A>, b in I, e in I) With res = pa(b, e) in R<A>:
      readable_bounded_range(b, e) implies
           (iter(res) in [b, e]
        && ka::empty(res) implies iter(res) = b)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
A parser is a function taking a range of symbols `[b, e)` as input and
returning a parsing result. If parsing failed, the result is empty and its
iterator `i` equals `b`. Otherwise, the result is non-empty, and `[b, i)`,
with `i in [b, e]`, is the subrange successfully parsed.

Added components (all in namespace `parse`)
===========================================

Type constructors
-----------------

With Type A, ForwardIterator I, Parser<A, I> PA:

- res_t: (Type, ForwardIterator) -> ParseResult
  Result of a parsing.

- symbol_t: Parser<A, I>
  Parser of a single symbol (generally speaking, the input of parser is a range
  of symbols, aka "characters").

- product_t: (Parser<A>...) -> Parser<ka::product_t<A...>>
  Sequencing parser. Applies all parsers until one fails, in left-to-right order.
  Succeeds if all parsers succeeded.

- unit_t = product_t<>
  Always successful parser. Neutral element (aka identity, aka unit) of product.

- sum_t: (Parser<A>...) -> Parser<boost::variant<indexed_t<0, A>...>>
  Alternative parser. Applies parsers until one succeeds, in left-to-right order.
  Succeeds if any parser succeeded.

- zero_t = sum_t<>
  Always unsuccessful parser. Neutral element of sum.

- quantify_t: (Parser<A>) -> Parser<std::vector<A>>
  Repetition parser. Applies another parser between min and max times (included).
  Its result is a collection of `A` containing between min and max (included)
  elements.


Constructor functions
---------------------

- ok: (A, I) -> res_t<A, I>
  Successful result.

- err: (type_t<A>, I) -> res_t<A, I>
  Unsuccessful result.

- symbol: symbol_t

- product: (PA...) -> product_t<PA...>

- unit: unit_t

- sum: (PA...) -> sum_t<PA...>

- opt: (PA) -> sum_t<PA, ka::unit>
  Optional parser. Always succeeds, even if couldn't parse `A`.

- quantify: (PA, std::size_t min, std::size_t max) -> quantify_t<PA>
- quantify: (PA, std::size_t min, ka::opt_t<std::size_t> max) -> quantify_t<PA>
- quantify: (PA, std::size_t min) -> quantify_t<PA>
  If max is not provided or is empty, there is no upper bound (i.e.
  max = infinity).

- list(pa) = quantify(pa, 0)
  Applies parser repeatedly until it fails (no upper bound). Always succeeds
  (note: if no `A` could be parsed, an empty collection is successfully
  returned).

Change-Id: I41301fe9d5948a408a70144cd483e3f16260eae9
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/97454
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
ka: Adds an `indexed_t` type.

A type that associates a type to an index.

This type is useful to dissociate same type alternative in union classes like
`boost::variant`, especially in generic code.

Example: Handling a `boost::variant` of the same type twice.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
boost::variant<int, int> v1 { 12 }; // It is unclear which alternative is used.
// auto i = boost::get<int>(v1); This won't compile because it's ambiguous.

boost::variant<ka::indexed_t<0, int>, ka::indexed_t<1, int>>
  v2 { ka::indexed<1>(42) }; // The chosen alternative is clear.
auto i = boost::get<ka::indexed_t<1, int>>(v2); // This call is unambiguous.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Change-Id: I8ad0d8ff3d343e77009bd888d0f3248967ab3da6
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/97372

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.zero: Adds the uninstantiable type `zero_t`.

Type with no instance.

Theoretically, it corresponds to the initial object in the category of
sets and functions, which is the empty set (i.e. the set with no element).
It is therefore the dual of `unit_t`.
It also happens to be (isomorphic to) the sum of no set, hence the
definition should be as an empty sum (but `boost::variant<>` and
`std::variant<>` are incomplete types, see TODO).

Warning: Abusing C++ type system is easy, and it is possible to form
  references or pointers to this uninstantiable type (e.g. with
  `(zero_t*)nullptr`). A good usage of this type of course excludes this
  kind of practices.

Warning: Copy constructor is not deactivated as a lot of existing code
  (`boost` libraries...) tends to instantiate types too greedily, and
  deactivation leads to a lot of artificial compilation problems. In a
  correct usage of this type, this lack should not be a problem since there
  is no value to copy in the first place.

meaning(zero_t) = 0

TODO: Make an alias of `ka::sum_t<>` when available.

Change-Id: I5e5ce5909592ec25c539d1d9e9446946aa55300f
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/97453
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.conceptpredicate: Adds the `is_functor` function.

True if the type is a mathematical functor for all the passed pairs of
composable functions.

A mathematical functor is a function `X` that sends morphisms `A -> B` to
morphisms `X(A) -> X(B)`, preserving composition. In our case, the mathematical
functor translates to a polymorphic function that "lifts" functions `A -> B` to
functions `X<A> -> X<B>` preserving function composition, where `X` models the
`Functor` concept (see `concept.hpp`).

This function lifts passed functions, then compares them through the given
equivalence.

Example: Checking that a type template models the `Functor` concept.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
// Pair of composable functions.
auto const f = [](A a) -> B {return B{2 * a.value};};
auto const g = [](B b) -> C {return C{b.value + 1};};

Here, `ka::fmap` will be used to (generically) lift `f` and `g`.
`my_functor_fn_equ` will be called with pairs of lifted functions and
decide if they are equivalent or not (for instance, by approximating
extensional equality and comparing functions outputs for a sample of
inputs). It is `my_functor_fn_equ` that determines which actual model of
`Functor` is tested, by calling the generically lifted functions with
appropriate `Functor` values (here of some `my_functor_t<T>` type).

EXPECT_TRUE(is_functor(
  ka::fmap,                    // function lifting
  array_fn(ka::product(g, f)), // pairs of composable functions
  my_functor_fn_equ            // equivalence of lifted functions
));
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Change-Id: Ib615e06aa1693d0df32ea0bfc4a6d0036b1fa94d
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/97452
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.messaging: Encrypts communication with TLS 1.2. (spec:/sbre/framework/2020/a) (#45377)

See <spec:/sbre/framework/2020/a> for an authoritative version of the following
text.

Foreword
========

`libqi` implements the `qi` messaging protocol, whose finality is to allow
communication between components of a distributed system.

One of its driving use case is robotics. The following text specifies a
development taking place in this context, therefore robotic details are
mentioned. That by no means contradicts the general nature of `libqi`.

Overall goal
============

The overall goal is to get a better security for communication amongst
components of the robot.

The broad "security" term notably includes:

- privacy:
The communication is only available to entities that initiated it (typically a
client and a server).

- authentication:
Each entity is able to verify the identity of other entities it communicates
with.

- data integrity:
Each entity can ensure that the data it receives is really what was sent, and
has not been altered in any way.

Development goal
================

Security team request
---------------------

> All communications should be encrypted to protect confidentiality and
> authenticity of both the Android and Linux operating systems and associated
> applications. That is mandatory that all communication between Android and Linux
> be encrypted. Following is the requirement for the TLS protocol to use for all
> communications between Android and Linux System in robot:
>
> - Only use TLS v1.2 and TLS v1.3.
>
> - The recommended cipher suites to use to secure the transfer of data are shown
> as follows:
>    - ECDHE-ECDSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256
>    - ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256
>    - ECDHE-ECDSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
>    - ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
>    - ECDHE-ECDSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305
>    - ECDHE-RSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305
>    - DHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256
>    - DHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384

Backward compatibility
======================

When this development is integrated, entities (desktop softwares, robots) will
coexist using different encryption protocols. Older ones are denoted here by
"SSL", newer ones by "TLS". What is the expected compatibility?

A distinction is made between clients (e.g. a desktop Choregraph) and servers
(e.g. a robot, via its gateway).

In the following matrix, a client tries to connect to a server:

client      |  SSL server  |  TLS server
----------- |:------------:| ------------
SSL client  | ok           | ko
TLS client  | ok           | ok

It is the server that determines which version is accepted, not the client, i.e.
adaptiveness is on client side.

Technical specification outlines
================================

The scope of the development is delimited by `libqi` as it is the central point
for communication management between components.

- Server components will force the use of TLS 1.2 (TLS 1.3 is not available in
  Boost.Asio 1.64, which is the currently supported version).

- Client components will use by default TLS 1.2, but will accept to downgrade
  down to SSL2.

- For security reason, no flag/option/environment variable will be provided to
  specify protocol (TLS 1.2, TLS 1.3...), their options, cipher list, etc.
  Instead, this information will be hardcoded in source code.

- Because all ciphers in the recommended cipher list use the
  [Diffie-Hellman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffie-Hellman) protocol (to
  securely exchange cryptographic keys over a public channel), [Diffie-Hellman
  parameters must be provided with a bit-length of
  3072](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/sp/800-57-part-2/rev-1/final).

  Diffie-Hellman parameters can be generated with the command `openssl dhparam
  -outform PEM -out dhparams.pem 3072`, and will also be hardcoded in source
  code.

Compatibility tests
-------------------

See dedicated section in [specifications](spec:/sbre/framework/2020/a).

In-context tests
----------------

See dedicated section in [specifications](spec:/sbre/framework/2020/a).

Annex
=====

Background information on SSL and TLS
-------------------------------------

What are SSL and TLS? How are they related? What is their compatibility?

- Presentation:

Transport Layer Security (TLS), and its now-deprecated predecessor, Secure
Sockets Layer (SSL), are cryptographic protocols designed to provide
communications security over a computer network. Several versions of the
protocols find widespread use in applications such as web browsing, email,
instant messaging, and voice over IP (VoIP). Websites can use TLS to secure all
communications between their servers and web browsers.

TLS is a proposed Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) standard, first defined
in 1999, and the current version is TLS 1.3 defined in RFC 8446 (August 2018).
TLS builds on the earlier SSL specifications (1994, 1995, 1996) developed by
Netscape Communications for addition the HTTPS protocol to their Navigator web
browser.[^2]

- High-level properties:

The TLS protocol aims primarily to provide privacy and data integrity between
two or more communicating computer applications. When secured by TLS,
connections between a client (e.g., a web browser) and a server (e.g.,
wikipedia.org) should have one or more of the following properties:

- The connection is private (or secure) because symmetric cryptography is used
to encrypt the data transmitted. The keys for this symmetric encryption are
generated uniquely for each connection and are based on a shared secret that
was negotiated at the start of the session (see § TLS handshake). The server
and client negotiate the details of which encryption algorithm and
cryptographic keys to use before the first byte of data is transmitted (see §
Algorithm below). The negotiation of a shared secret is both secure (the
negotiated secret is unavailable to eavesdroppers and cannot be obtained, even
by an attacker who places themselves in the middle of the connection) and
reliable (no attacker can modify the communications during the negotiation
without being detected).

- The identity of the communicating parties can be authenticated using
public-key cryptography. This authentication can be made optional, but is
generally required for at least one of the parties (typically the server).

- The connection is reliable because each message transmitted includes a
message integrity check using a message authentication code to prevent
undetected loss or alteration of the data during transmission.[^2]

[^2]: [SSL/TLS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer)

History
-------

protocol | published    | status
-------- | ------------ | -----------------------------
SSL 1.0  | unpublished  | unpublished
SSL 2.0  | 1995         | deprecated in 2011 (RFC 6176)
SSL 3.0  | 1996         | deprecated in 2015 (RFC 7568)
TLS 1.0  | 1999         | deprecation planned in 2020
TLS 1.1  | 2006         | deprecation planned in 2020
TLS 1.2  | 2008         |
TLS 1.3  | 2018         |

SSL / TLS compatibility
-----------------------

"the differences between this protocol [TLS 1.0] and SSL 3.0 are not dramatic,
but they are significant enough to preclude interoperability between TLS 1.0
and SSL 3.0. TLS 1.0 does include a means by which a TLS implementation can
downgrade the connection to SSL 3.0, thus weakening security." [^3]

- After TLS 1.2:

"All TLS versions were further refined in RFC 6176 in March 2011, removing
their backward compatibility with SSL such that TLS sessions never negotiate
the use of Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) version 2.0."[^4]

- TLS 1.3:

"• Prohibiting SSL or RC4 negotiation for backwards compatibility" [^5]

[^3]: [SSL-TLS 1.0 compat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security#TLS_1.0)
[^4]: [SSL2-TLS1.2 compat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#TLS_1.2)
[^5]: [SSL-TLS1.3 compat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#TLS_1.3)

Support of TLS 1.3
------------------

library    | version | date of release
---------- | ------- | ---------------
wolfSSL    | 3.11.1  | 2017/05
OpenSSL    | 1.1.1   | 2018/09
Boost.Asio | 1.69    | 2018/12

Current backward compatibility of TLS with SSL
----------------------------------------------

As of December 2019:

TLS      | SSL 2.0         | SSL 3.0
-------- | --------------- | ------------------
TLS 1.0  | no (see Note 1) | no
TLS 1.2  | no (see Note 1) | yes
TLS 1.3  | no              | no

Note 1: Yes until 2011/03, if downgrade is activated.

TLS handshake
-------------

```
Client                 Server
  | ClientHello (1)       |
  |---------------------->|
  |                       |
  | ServerHello (2)       |
  |<----------------------|
  |                       |
  | Certificate           |
  |<----------------------|
  |                       |
  | ServerKeyExchange     |
  |<----------------------|
  |                       |
  | ServerHelloDone       |
  |<----------------------|
  |                       |
  | ClientKeyExchange (3) |
  |---------------------->|
  |                       |
  |--                   --|
  |  |(4)           (4)|  |
  |<-                   ->|
  |                       |
  | ChangeCipherSpec      |
  |---------------------->|
  |                       |
  | Finished (5)          |
  |---------------------->|
  |                       |
  | ChangeCipherSpec      |
  |<----------------------|
  |                       |
  | Finished (6)          |
  |<----------------------|
```

(1) Containing essentially:
- the highest supported TLS version
- a random number
- list of accepted cipher suites and compression methods

(2) Containing:
- the chosen TLS version
- a random number
- the chosen cipher suite and compression method

(3) Containing the PreMasterSecret.

(4) The client and server then use the random numbers and PreMasterSecret to
compute a common secret, called the "master secret". All other key data for this
connection is derived from this master secret.

(5) Containing a hash and MAC over the previous handshake messages. If the
decryption or verification fails, the handshake is considered to have failed and
the connection should be torn down.

TLS Attacks
-----------

Various attacks operate by downgrading TLS.

"The Heartbleed bug is a serious vulnerability specific to the implementation of
SSL/TLS in the popular OpenSSL cryptographic software library, affecting
versions 1.0.1 to 1.0.1f." [^6]

[^6]: [Attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security#Attacks_against_TLS/SSL)

Miscellaneous
-------------

A paper presented at the 2012 ACM conference on computer and communications
security showed that few applications used some of these SSL libraries
correctly, leading to vulnerabilities. According to the authors

"the root cause of most of these vulnerabilities is the terrible design of the
APIs to the underlying SSL libraries. Instead of expressing high-level security
properties of network tunnels such as confidentiality and authentication, these
APIs expose low-level details of the SSL protocol to application developers. As
a consequence, developers often use SSL APIs incorrectly, misinterpreting and
misunderstanding their manifold parameters, options, side effects, and return
values." [^7]

[^7]: [Implem errors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#Implementation_errors:_Heartbleed_bug,_BERserk_attack,_Cloudflare_bug)

Differences between Boost.Asio 1.64 and Boost.Asio 1.71
-------------------------------------------------------

There are no significant difference relative to ssl/tls. One update is the
addition of `TLSv1.3` support [^8] [^9].

- `ssl::context::method`: Adds `tlsv13`, `tlsv13_client`, `tlsv13_server`.

- `ssl::context` (via `ssl::context_base`): Adds `no_tlsv1_3` option.

[^8]: [boost.asio context 1.64](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_64_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/ssl__context.html)
[^9]: [boost.asio context 1.71](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_71_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/ssl__context.html)

RFC
---

  Reference: [RFC5246](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5246)

  > 1.2.  Major Differences from TLS 1.1
  >
  >   - Support for the SSLv2 backward-compatible hello is now a MAY, not
  >   a SHOULD, with sending it a SHOULD NOT.  Support will probably
  >   become a SHOULD NOT in the future.

  > Appendix B.  Glossary
  >
  >   - SSL
  >       Netscape's Secure Socket Layer protocol [SSL3].  TLS is based on
  >       SSL Version 3.0.

  > E.1.  Compatibility with TLS 1.0/1.1 and SSL 3.0
  >
  >   TLS versions 1.0, 1.1, and 1.2, and SSL 3.0 are very similar, and use
  >   compatible ClientHello messages; thus, supporting all of them is
  >   relatively easy.  Similarly, servers can easily handle clients trying
  >   to use future versions of TLS as long as the ClientHello format
  >   remains compatible, and the client supports the highest protocol
  >   version available in the server.

  TLS includes a version negotiation mechanism. Thus, TLS versions 1.0, 1.1,
  and 1.2, and SSL 3.0 can be made compatible, as a matter of client and server
  configuration.

  > E.2.  Compatibility with SSL 2.0
  >
  >   TLS 1.2 clients SHOULD NOT support SSL 2.0.
  >

  Reference: [RFC2246](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2246)

  > 3. Goals of this document
  >
  >   This document and the TLS protocol itself are based on the SSL 3.0
  >   Protocol Specification as published by Netscape. The differences
  >   between this protocol and SSL 3.0 are not dramatic, but they are
  >   significant enough that TLS 1.0 and SSL 3.0 do not interoperate
  >   (although TLS 1.0 does incorporate a mechanism by which a TLS
  >   implementation can back down to SSL 3.0).

  > E. Backward Compatibility With SSL
  >
  >    For historical reasons and in order to avoid a profligate consumption
  >    of reserved port numbers, application protocols which are secured by
  >    TLS 1.0, SSL 3.0, and SSL 2.0 all frequently share the same
  >    connection port: for example, the https protocol (HTTP secured by SSL
  >    or TLS) uses port 443 regardless of which security protocol it is
  >    using. Thus, some mechanism must be determined to distinguish and
  >    negotiate among the various protocols.
  >
  >    TLS version 1.0 and SSL 3.0 are very similar; thus, supporting both
  >    is easy. TLS clients who wish to negotiate with SSL 3.0 servers
  >    should send client hello messages using the SSL 3.0 record format and
  >    client hello structure, sending {3, 1} for the version field to note
  >    that they support TLS 1.0. If the server supports only SSL 3.0, it
  >    will respond with an SSL 3.0 server hello; if it supports TLS, with a
  >    TLS server hello. The negotiation then proceeds as appropriate for
  >    the negotiated protocol.
  >
  >    Similarly, a TLS server which wishes to interoperate with SSL 3.0
  >    clients should accept SSL 3.0 client hello messages and respond with
  >    an SSL 3.0 server hello if an SSL 3.0 client hello is received which
  >    has a version field of {3, 0}, denoting that this client does not
  >    support TLS.

  Reference: [RFC4346](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4346)

SSL debugging
-------------

- OpenSSL tools

OpenSSL provides commands to start debug clients and servers. It is possible to
specify the "SSL method" (ssl2_3, tls1_2, etc.), the cipher suite, etc.

```console
$ openssl s_server -port 54323 -tls1_2 -cert ./tests/messaging/libtestsession/share/qi/server.crt \
-key ./tests/messaging/libtestsession/share/qi/server.key -cipher DHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:\
ECDHE-ECDSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:\
ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:ECDHE-ECDSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305:ECDHE-RSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305:\
DHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
```

```console
$ openssl s_client -connect 127.0.0.1:54323 -tls1_2 -cipher ECDHE-ECDSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:\
ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:\
ECDHE-ECDSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305:ECDHE-RSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305:DHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:\
DHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
```

- Wireshark / Tshark

These tools can capture network data between a client and a server, and dissect
data in a clear manner.

Sources
=======

SSL/TLS: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer)

SSL-TLS 1.0 compat: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security#TLS_1.0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security#TLS_1.0)

SSL2-TLS1.2 compat: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#TLS_1.2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#TLS_1.2)

SSL-TLS1.3 compat: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#TLS_1.3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#TLS_1.3)

Attacks: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security#Attacks_against_TLS/SSL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security#Attacks_against_TLS/SSL)

Implem errors: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#Implementation_errors:_Heartbleed_bug,_BERserk_attack,_Cloudflare_bug](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Sockets_Layer#Implementation_errors:_Heartbleed_bug,_BERserk_attack,_Cloudflare_bug)

boost.asio context 1.64: [https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_64_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/ssl__context.html](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_64_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/ssl__context.html)

boost.asio context 1.71: [https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_71_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/ssl__context.html](https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_71_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/ssl__context.html)

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.log: Adds the helper `InvokeCatchLogRethrow`.

Allows one to invoke a procedure, catching any exception, logging details in the
specified log level, and rethrowing the exception, if any.

Removed components
==================

Type constructors
-----------------

- ExceptionLogError: (OStreamable, ConvertibleTo<const char*>)
    -> PolymorphicProcedure<void (std::exception || boost::exception || )>

Constructor functions
---------------------

With OStreamable O, ConvertibleTo<const char*> S:

- exceptionLogError: (OStreamable O, ConvertibleTo<const char*> S) -> ExceptionLogError

Added components
================

Type constructors
-----------------

With LogLevel L:

- ExceptionLog<L>: (OStreamable, ConvertibleTo<const char*>) ->
    PolymorphicProcedure<void (std::exception || boost::exception || )>

  Logs an exception in the log at the specified level, distinguishing
  std::exception, boost::exception and unknown exception (typically for the
  `catch (...)` case).

- ExceptionLogSilent  = ExceptionLog<LogLevel_Silent>
- ExceptionLogFatal   = ExceptionLog<LogLevel_Fatal>
- ExceptionLogError   = ExceptionLog<LogLevel_Error>
- ExceptionLogWarning = ExceptionLog<LogLevel_Warning>
- ExceptionLogInfo    = ExceptionLog<LogLevel_Info>
- ExceptionLogVerbose = ExceptionLog<LogLevel_Verbose>
- ExceptionLogDebug   = ExceptionLog<LogLevel_Debug>

Partially applied versions for the corresponding log level.

With LogLevel L, ConvertibleTo<const char*> S, OStreamable O,
  Procedure<_ (Args...)> Proc, Res = CodomainFor<Proc, Args...>:

- InvokeCatchLogRethrow<L>: PolymorphicProcedure<(S, O, Proc, Args...) -> Res>

  Polymorphic procedure that invokes a procedure, catching any exception,
  logging details, and rethrowing the exception, if any.

  Example: Creating a resource, logging in error any exception and rethrowing it.
  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  InvokeCatchLogRethrow<LogLevel_Error> call; // Or `InvokeCatchLogRethrowError call;`
  auto resource = call(
    "resource creation",             // log category
    "could not create the resource", // log prefix
    createResource,                  // auto (string, Mode)
    name,                            // first argument of `createResource`
    readOnly                         // second argument of `createResource`
  );
  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

- InvokeCatchLogRethrowSilent  = InvokeCatchLogRethrow<LogLevel_Silent>
- InvokeCatchLogRethrowFatal   = InvokeCatchLogRethrow<LogLevel_Fatal>
- InvokeCatchLogRethrowError   = InvokeCatchLogRethrow<LogLevel_Error>
- InvokeCatchLogRethrowWarning = InvokeCatchLogRethrow<LogLevel_Warning>
- InvokeCatchLogRethrowInfo    = InvokeCatchLogRethrow<LogLevel_Info>
- InvokeCatchLogRethrowDebug   = InvokeCatchLogRethrow<LogLevel_Debug>

Partially applied versions for the corresponding log level.

Constructor functions
---------------------

With LogLevel L, OStreamable O, ConvertibleTo<const char*> S:

- exceptionLog<L>: (O, S) -> ExceptionLog<L, O, S>

- exceptionLogSilent  = exceptionLog<LogLevel_Silent>
- exceptionLogFatal   = exceptionLog<LogLevel_Fatal>
- exceptionLogError   = exceptionLog<LogLevel_Error>
- exceptionLogWarning = exceptionLog<LogLevel_Warning>
- exceptionLogInfo    = exceptionLog<LogLevel_Info>
- exceptionLogVerbose = exceptionLog<LogLevel_Verbose>
- exceptionLogDebug   = exceptionLog<LogLevel_Debug>

Partially applied versions for the corresponding log level.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.errorhandling: Adds helpers, fixes naming and gets better documentation.

Added constructor functions
===========================

With
  ```
  Handler = PolymorphicProcedure<_ (_), _ ()>,
  ExceptionHandler = PolymorphicProcedure<Ret (std::exception const&), Ret (boost::exception const&), Ret ()>,
  Handler Proc0,
  ExceptionHandler Proc1,
  Procedure<Ret (_...)> F
  ```:

- `handle_exception_rethrow: (Proc0, type_t<Ret> = type_t<void>{}) -> handle_exception_rethrow_t<Proc0, Ret>`

- `invoke_catch_fn: (Proc1, F) -> invoke_catch_fn_t<Proc1, F>`

Added type constructors
=======================

- `invoke_catch_fn_t: (ExceptionHandler, Procedure<Ret (_...)>) -> Procedure<Ret (_...)>`
  Procedure that invokes a procedure in a try-catch clause and delegates
  exception handling to a dedicated handler.

Renaming
========

- `handle_exception_rethrow` -> `handle_exception_rethrow_t`
- `exception_value` -> `exception_value_t`
- `exception_message` -> `exception_message_t`

New feature
===========

- `handle_exception_rethrow_t` has now an optional second type parameter to
  specify its codomain (default is `void`).

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.iterator: Adds operators for iterators.

It is useful to write generic code that accepts indistinctly arithmetic types and
iterator types.

For example, incrementing arithmetic types and iterator types is similar. Same
for the distance between two numbers / iterators. In the case of iterators, the
complexity of these operations depends on the iterator category.

For a formal justification of these operators, see [Elements of Programming
(Stepanov-MacJones, 2009)](http://elementsofprogramming.com/), section 6.3.

data.message:
qi.tests: Fixes a use-after-destroyed problem.

In a test, `AutoAnyReference` creates an `AnyReference` to a double
literal. `AnyReference` acts as a pointer and therefore does not copy
the value.
This patch just stores the value before creating the reference so that
it stays alive long enough.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
ka: Moves preprocessor macros from `qi` to `ka`.

This patch moves a few macro implementations from `qi/macro.hpp` into
`ka/macro.hpp`.

This allows us to use them in files from the `ka` library and its tests.

The macros that have been changed are the following:
  - QI_DO_PRAGMA becomes KA_PRAGMA.
  - QI_MSG_PRAGMA becomes KA_PRAGMA_MESSAGE.
  - QI_COMPILER_WARNING becomes KA_WARNING.
  - QI_WARNING_PUSH becomes KA_WARNING_PUSH.
  - QI_WARNING_DISABLE becomes KA_WARNING_DISABLE.
  KA_WARNING_DISABLE can now also take an empty code or name to
  disable a warning respectively only on GCC/Clang or MSVC.
  - QI_WARNING_POP becomes KA_WARNING_POP.

The original macros are kept for compatibility and to hide the
implementations from `ka` to libqi users.

Change-Id: I6039aff3c79c061fd51a82b9212a19e3058b9f6b
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/96817

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
ka.utility: Adds a type to pass types as values.

It is implemented as a constant variadic type function to the unit type, i.e. a
function that sends any sequence of types to the unit type.

Added components
================

- Type functions (where `Type` is the concept modeled by any type, `Unit` is the
  concept modeled by any type isomorphic to `unit_t` such as any type without
  member):

  + constant_unit_t: (Type...) -> Unit
  + ConstantUnit:    (Type...) -> Unit (applied version)
  + type_t:          (Type...) -> Unit (alias to constant_unit_t)

`type_t`
========

Convenient type to pass types as values.

It can be used to partially specialize function templates.

Example: Partially specializing a function template.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
// A PolymorphicDeserializer is a polymorphic function that deserializes
// values of several types out of a bounded range.

// concept PolymorphicDeserializer(T) =
//  Function<auto (type_t<A>, I, I) -> std::pair<opt_t<A>, I>>(T)
//    where Type(A), InputIterator<char>(I)
//    where Type is the concept modeled by any type.

// InputIterator<char> I
template<typename I>
auto deserialize(type_t<int>, I b, I e) -> std::pair<opt_t<int>, I> {
  ...
}

// InputIterator<char> I
template<typename I>
auto deserialize(type_t<bool>, I b, I e) -> std::pair<opt_t<bool>, I> {
  ...
}

One of the extra benefits of passing a type as a function parameter is
that it is possible to "bind" this parameter to monomorphize the
function, or to delegate this decision to another function by forwarding
arguments.

Note: It can also acts as a product of types, i.e. it is possible to extract a
type back with `std::tuple_element`.

Change-Id: I3058bf7768a6fdb6abe7b198456ab138123aa11a
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/96818
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: julien.bernard <julien.bernard@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.relationpredicate: Adds a predicate for the complement of a relation.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Property(Relation R0, Relation R1)
  requires(Domain(R0) = Domain(R1))
are_complement: R0 x R1
 (r0, r1) |-> (forall a, b in the domain of R0) r0(a, b) != r1(a, b)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
A relation r0 is the complement of another relation r1 iff for all pairs of
element exactly one of these two relations holds at a time.

Example: "equal" and "different", "less than" and "greater or equal"

Change-Id: If976b567e31c5cfaef0b93dbc2e18cdb35e70492

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.functional: Makes accumulation composition returns the last accumulation result.

Though an accumulation returns `void`, it can be useful to relax this
restriction:

- an "accumulation" could return another type than `void`, for instance a
  Regular "unit" type allowing for better interoperability with the rest of the
  language (since a unit value can be put into other objects, compared, etc.,
  making unnecessary a lot of `void` special cases)

- occasionally, it can also be useful to return a non-unit value. For instance,
  when composing steps of an algorithm, the last step may return a useful value.
  In this case, the step is not stricto sensu an accumulation and we want to
  return the value to the user.

Change-Id: Id09317d0a5d4846ad0ccbecdf445ce2e3ac00be1
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/92504
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: julien.bernard <julien.bernard@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.functional: Adds retraction of composition.

A composition can be interpreted as a sequence of two steps (say, `putSocks`
then `putShoes`). Retracting (i.e. undoing) this sequence means retracting the
second step (`removeShoes`), then the first (`removeSocks`).

This means of course that a composition can only be retracted if its steps are.
Translated in terms of concepts, we have (where `=>` is to be read 'implies'):

- RetractableFunction(F) && RetractableFunction(G) => RetractableFunction(composition_t<G, F>)

- IsomorphicAction(F) && IsomorphicAction(G) => IsomorphicAction(composition_accu_t<G, F>)

(a retractable action is always isomorphic due to the domain and codomain being the same)

Change-Id: Id4ad76160c0475685f38c124766f673544564fb7
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/92411
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: matthieu.paindavoine <matthieu.paindavoine@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.functor: Adds functor support.

Added components
================

See next sections for a formal definition of `Functor` and `FunctorApp`
concepts.

- `Functor`-related functions (with Function<(A) -> B> F, Functor T):
    + fmap: (F, T<A>) -> T<B>
    + fmap: (F) -> ((T<A>) -> T<B>) // Partial application version.

- `FunctorApp`-related functions (with Function<(A, B...) -> C> G, Functor T):
    + fmap: (G, T<A>, T<B>...) -> T<C>
    + fmap: (G) -> ((T<A>, T<B>...) -> T<C>) // Partial application version.

`ka::fmap` algorithm
================

```
if a `fmap` function is found through `ADL`:
  call it
else if the type has a member `fmap`:
  call it
else if `fmap_dispatch(false_t, F, T...)` is defined:
  call it (if this specialization comes from `functorcontainer.hpp`, a
    standard container is assumed)
```

Concepts
========

Functor
-------

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
concept Functor(T) =
    Regular(T<A>)
 && fmap: F x T<A> -> T<B>, where Function<B (A)> F
 && With `g ∘ f` denoting `compose(g, f)`,
         `fmap(h)` denoting partial function application of `fmap`,
         id_transfo_t id,
         `==` denoting function extensional equality (i.e. two functions are
         equal if for all inputs they have the same output):
      fmap(id) == id                   (preservation of identity)
   && fmap(g ∘ f) == fmap(g) ∘ fmap(f) (preservation of composition)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

A functor is a projection of objects and morphisms (here resp., types
and functions) that preserves identity and morphism composition.

The `Functor` concept implements the type projection through a template type,
and the function projection (also called sometimes 'lifting') through the
function `fmap`.

Note: Projected functions are unary. See concept `FunctorApp` for n-ary
functions.

The functor notion notably allows one to dissociate the work to apply to a value
placed inside a data structure (the "what"), from how to actually apply it
inside the data structure (the "how"). But beware that not all functor
models are container-like, such as functions with a given domain, or
futures.

Typical models are: std containers, std::optional, functions with a given
domain, futures, etc.

FunctorApp
----------

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
concept FunctorApp(T) =
    Functor(T)
 && fmap: F x T<A> x ... -> T<Z>, where Function<Z (A x ...)> F
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Functor that allows one to apply a n-ary function. The name is reminiscent of
the notion of `Applicative` functor found in other languages.

Typical models are: non-key/value std containers (e.g. this includes
`std::set` but excludes `std::map`), std::optional, futures, etc.

Models
======

Type constructor     Models `Functor`    Models `FunctorApp`
-------------------- ------------------- -------------------
`std::array`                 x                   x
`std::vector`                x                   x
`std::deque`                 x                   x
`std::forward_list`          x                   x
`std::list`                  x                   x
`std::set`                   x                   x
`std::multiset`              x                   x
`std::unordered_set`         x                   x
`std::unordered_multiset`    x                   x
`std::map`                   x
`std::multimap`              x
`std::unordered_map`         x
`std::unordered_multimap`    x
`ka::opt_t`                  x                   x
`boost::optional`            x                   x

Note: `std::*map` containers are functors only when the key type is considered
  bound. This is because a functor projects one type, not two. For instance,
  `std::map<std::string, _>` is a functor (key type is bound to `std::string`,
  value type remains free), not `std::map` by itself. Applying the "lifting" of
  a function `int -> bool` on a `std::map<std::string, int>` will yield a
  `std::map<std::string, bool>`.

Note: Since functions with a given domain are functors, `fmap` is implemented
  for `std::functor`. `std::functor` does not model `Functor` though, as it is
  not `Regular` (equality is missing).

`fmap` algorithm on containers
==============================

`fmap` algorithm for containers parametrized by *one value type*
----------------------------------------------------------------

  This includes `vector`, `list`, `set`, ...
  Create a new container by applying the mapped function to each value.

  Specification (`{x...}` denotes a container with values `x...`):
    `fmap(f, {x...}) = {f(x)...}`

  In the `FunctorApp` case, several containers are passed:
    `fmap(f, {x...}, {y...}, ...) = {f(x, y, ...)...}`

  Note: The resulting container's size is the smallest of the input
    containers' sizes. E.g.
    `fmap(f,
        {x0, x1, x2},
        {y0, y1},
        {z0, z1, z2, z3}) =
      {f(x0, y0, z0), f(x1, y1, z1)}`

`fmap` algorithm for containers parametrized by *one key type and one value type*
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  This includes `map`, `multimap`, `unordered_map`, ...
  Create a new container by copying keys and applying the mapped function to
  each value only.

  Specification (`{(k, x)...}` denotes a container with keys/value pairs
    `(k, x)...`):
    `fmap(f, {(k, x)...}) = {(k, f(x))...}`

  I.e. the function is applied on values only (see justification in the
  `Models` section).

  Note: At the moment, `FunctorApp` is not modeled by `key/value` containers,
    due to a more difficult traversal and/or key reduction problems.

Change-Id: Idbe23b8560a29ecf4a24dba0d14510eba8fd0e3d
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/96230
Reviewed-by: julien.bernard <julien.bernard@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.ServiceDirectoryProxy: Tunes down a log warning.

Fixes #45095.

The service directory proxy code logs a warning when it fails to attach
to the service directory, explaining that it's going to try attaching
again after a delay. This warning often happens at the start of NAOqi
when the public gateway starts faster than the public service directory
and therefore fails to attach to it. This tends to alert the testers for
no good reason.

This patch just tunes down the log from warning to verbose.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.MessageDispatcher: Reduces memory usage by removing recipient ids that are not needed anymore.

In MessageDispatcher, when all handlers for a recipient were
removed, the recipient ID would still be left in the recipients map,
associated with an empty handlers map. As objects are
serialized/deserialized, they add new recipient IDs to the map but
never remove them. So the map grows and never shrinks even long after
the objects have been destroyed.

This patch removes the recipient ID from the map once there is no more
handler for it.

Fixes #45064.

Change-Id: I8548b5e057b5c3681626aae172c7eecb655dd666
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/96988

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
ka.typetraits: Adds the `ka::ConstantVoid` type function.

It is useful to create type predicates based on expressions. It is an
alternative to the `KA_GENERATE_TRAITS_HAS` macro.

Added components
================

- Type functions (where `Type` is the concept modeled by any type):
  + ConstantVoid: Type... -> Type
    ConstantVoid<A...> == void

Examples
========

Example: Defining a type predicate true iff a value of the type can be
  assigned with an `int`, and using it to dispatch a function call.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
template<typename T, typename = void>
struct IsIntAssignable : false_t {};

template<typename T>
struct IsIntAssignable<
  T, ConstantVoid<decltype(declref<T>() = 1)>> : true_t {};

template<typename T>
void try_set_impl(T& t, int i, true_t /* is int-assignable */) {
  t = i;
}

template<typename T>
void try_set_impl(T& t, int i, false_t /* is NOT int-assignable */) {
  // nothing.
}

template<typename T>
void try_set(T& t, int i) {
  try_set_impl(t, i, typename IsIntAssignable<T>::type{});
}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Change-Id: I8c7d8f624ac7c8d3a2fed325afb9f9bed071fb07
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/96738
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: julien.bernard <julien.bernard@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.iter: Implements the product of iterators.

A product of iterators can be used to iterate through several containers at
once.

Added components
================

See next sections for background information.

- Type contructors:
    + `product_iter_t: InputIterator... -> InputIterator`

- Constructor functions (with InputIterator... I, Linearizable... L):
    + `product_iter: I... -> product_iter_t<I...>`
    + `product_begin: L... -> product_iter_t<Iterator<L>...>`
    + `product_end: L... -> product_iter_t<Iterator<L>...>`
    + `product_end_same_size: L... -> product_iter_t<Iterator<L>...>`

- Functions (with InputIterator... I, InputIterator J, K):
    + `proj<n>: product_iter_t<I...> -> I_n` (i.e. nth type in I...)
    + `iterator_cat_ops::operator*`: J * K -> product_iter_t<J, K>

- Types:
    + `unit_iter_t: InputIterator`

- Constants:
    + `unit_iter: unit_iter_t`

Background
==========

A product of iterators groups sub-iterators and advances, dereferences, etc.,
them all at once.

The term of product is used in the categorical sense: it strictly groups
sub-iterators with no extra-information, and comes with projections to get
them back. The underlying category is constructed over that of discrete
dynamical systems (sets equipped with a transformation), with the additional
structure of dereferencement.
See [Conceptual Mathematics, (Lawvere-Schanuel, 2009)](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/conceptual-mathematics/00772F4CC3D4268200C5EC86B39D415A), article III

This iterator has the lowest iterator category of its sub-iterators, the
order being: input < forward < bidirectional < random access.

To construct a product of iterators, use the dedicated constructor functions:
`product_iter`, `product_begin`, `product_end`, `product_end_same_size`

Note: The operations of the product of iterators are specified in terms of
  laws (invariants). The following notation is used:
    - `i * j` denotes product of iterators `i` and `j`
    - `t * u` denotes product of values `t` and `u`, i.e. tuple of `t` and `u`
    - `n` denotes a signed integer
    - `i + n` denotes iterator `i` moved forward by `n` steps
    - `j - i` denotes distance from iterator `i` to iterator `j`
    - `1i` denotes iterator unit
    - `1` denotes unit
    - `=` denotes equality
    - `≅` denotes isomorphism

Laws:
    *(i * ...)  =  ((*i) * ...)            (dereferencement)
 && (i * ...) + n  =  (i + n) * ...        (forward / backward move)
 && (j * ...) - (i * ...)  =  n, such that
      (j * ...)  =  (i * ...) + n, that is
      + is a right group action.           (difference)
 && i * 1i  ≅  1i * i  ≅  i                (multiplication by unit)
 && 1i + n  =  1i                          (rest state 1)
 && 1i - 1i  =  0                          (rest state 2)
 && *1i  =  1                              (dereferencement of unit)

Note: Output iterators are not supported as their behavior differs too much
  from other iterator categories (`void` value type, etc.).

Examples
========

Example: Iterating through several containers at once.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
// Containers are assumed to be large enough.
// std::vector<X> v;
// std::array<Y, 10> a;
auto b = product_iter(v.begin(), a.begin());
auto e = product_iter(v.begin() + 2, a.begin() + 2);
while (b != e) {
  auto values = *b; // `values` has type `std::tuple<X, Y>`.
  ... // Use `values` (`ka::apply` can be used to call non-tuple input functions.)
  ++b;
}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Example: Iterating through several containers with different sizes.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
// Computing the end product iterator is O(n) since we have to determine the
// smallest container first.
// std::vector<X> v;  // size = 4
// std::list<Y> l;    // size = 2
// std::deque<Z> d;   // size = 10
// `product_begin(v, l, d) == product_iter(v.begin(), l.begin(), d.begin())`
auto b = product_begin(v, l, d);
auto e = product_end(v, l, d); // Ends depends on the smallest container.
// Will loop twice since the smallest container has size 2.
while (b != e) {
  auto values = *b; // `values` has type `std::tuple<X, Y, Z>`.
  ... // Use `values` (`ka::apply` can be used to call non-tuple input functions.)
  ++b;
}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Example: Iterating through several containers with same size.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
// Computing the end product iterator is O(1) since we know all containers
// have same size.
// std::vector<X> v;  // size = 4
// std::list<Y> l;    // size = 4
// std::deque<Z> d;   // size = 4
auto b = product_begin(v, l, d);
auto e = product_end_same_size(v, l, d); // Takes end iterator of each container.
// Will loop four times.
while (b != e) {
  auto values = *b; // `values` has type `std::tuple<X, Y, Z>`.
  ... // Use `values` (`ka::apply` can be used to call non-tuple input functions.)
  ++b;
}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.base64: Adds components to encode binary data to base64.

These components are:

- Types:
    + base64_iter_t: ForwardIterator<char> -> ForwardIterator<char>

- Algorithms (with ForwardIterator<char> I, OutputIterator<char> O):
    + base64_encode: (I, I, O) -> O
    + base64_encode_with_padding: (I, I, O) -> O
    + base64_encode: (I, I) -> std::string
    + base64_encode_with_padding: (I, I) -> std::string

- Utility functions (with Integral N):
    + base64_padding_byte_count: N -> N
    + base64_encoded_byte_count: N -> N
    + base64_encoded_with_padding_byte_count: N -> N

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.messaging: Makes socket cache return a better error message.

Fixes #42944.

When no endpoint was acceptable to the `TransportSocketCache`, the
`ConnectionAttempt` would end up being destroyed without being added to
the map of attempts, which resulted in a "Promise broken" error back to
the user, that could occur for example when the user used
`Session::service`.

This patch adds a destructor to `ConnectionAttempt` so that if the
promise is still running, an error is set with a better message than
just "Promise broken".

Change-Id: Ia14441ba8d6f8140c21eeeb7ef0f0870bd72baf7
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/96229
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
qi.messaging: Replaces service uid by a string representation. #94837

Also adds string serialization for ObjectUid.

This is a retro-compatibility fix:
Libqi tries to read the type of a field that should be ignored in case
of struct extension, which is a bug. If the type is not known, it
incorrectly triggers an error (as the field should not have been
observed).
Unfortunately we cannot easily upgrade all user code, so for now we will
use a string as it is a type known by all libqi versions.

Change-Id: I142947946acfb1aa47f808f73e24fc8b351d2693

A leak occurred when using the `qi::makeDynamicSharedAnyObject` function.

The leak was reproduced by running the test "test_messaging
--gtest_filter=Connection.testSyncSendOneMessage" repeatedly.

This patch deprecates the `qi::makeDynamicSharedAnyObject` function and
one of the constructors of `qi::Object` and replaces their uses in a
couple of places in libqi by `qi::makeDynamicAnyObject`.

data.message:
logs: Improves a few log messages to ease issue analysis. #44829

This change follows commit f522465d
  "logs: Changed info level logs to verbose level. 44672".

Sets consistent prefix to threadpool loop messages:
  "Threadpool <pool_name>:".

Changes to Info level following messages:
* Info: "Registered Service \"<service_name>\" (#<service_id>)"
* Info: "Unregistered Service \"<service_name>\" (#<service_id>)"

Enriches and changes to Info level "Spawning more threads" message:
Examples:
* Info: "Spawning 1 more thread. New size: 5 (min: 2, max: 8, size/min: 250%, size/max: 62%, growth ratio: 50% (3/6))"
* Info: "Spawning 1 more thread. New size: 8 (min: 2, max: 8, size/min: 400%, size/max: 100%, growth ratio: 100% (6/6)"
* Info: "Spawning 1 more thread. New size: 10 (min: 8, max: 150, size/min: 125%, size/max: 6%, growth ratio: 1% (2/142))"
NB "size/max" and "growth ratio" are specified only when the pool is growable to a limit (i.e. min < max, and thus max != 0).

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.type: Fixes a race between future destruction and cancellation.

Fixes #44862, #44841, #44025.

This patch fixes a race condition between the cancellation of a future
and its destruction. It could happen when the cancel request was
processed at the same time as the value was set. The conversion steps of
the value would result in the destruction of the result of an initial
`metacall` which could be accessed at the same time by a `cancel` call.

This patch binds the call to the cancel to a `shared_ptr` of the value,
resulting in a delay of its destruction until after the cancel.

Change-Id: I99e2f5cf13d1f3cf446ffe4e69e78d71f3c90e2a
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/96445
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
future: Adds a polymorphic function to return a Future with an error.

The future error message is the exception message.
A transformation can be specified to change the error message before
giving it to the future. This transformation is the identity by default.

Example: Calling an asynchronous function and returning an error in case
         of an exception.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
 auto res = invoke_catch(
   futureErrorFromException<int>,
   []() -> Future<int> {
     throw std::runtime_error("error");
   }
  );
  assert(res.hasError());
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Change-Id: I4465631453567bbbe86826e053250e0daac0bd00

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
messaging: Fixes a deadlock between ObjectHost and BoundObject.

In some cases, a deadlock could occur between `ObjectHost::removeObject`
and `BoundObject::unbindFromSocket`. The first function destroys the
SocketBindings of a BoundObject which calls the second function, which
then calls `ObjectHost::removeObjectsFromSocket`.

Both the first and the last functions share access to a
`synchronized_value`. This patch fixes it by unlocking the
`synchronized_value` in `ObjectHost` before destroying the BoundObjects
SocketBindings.

Change-Id: Ia7da928ec8427b16ca454eade99a92cce0d362ff
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/95974

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
messaging: Refactors message dispatch. #42553

This patch:

  - Entirely reworks how `BoundObject` and `RemoteObject` subscribe to
  sockets to receive their messages (remote objects do not received all
  messages that arrive on a socket).

  - Accordingly simplifies `MessageDispatcher::dispatch` implementation
  (also removes some dead code of the class).

  - Entirely reworks `ObjectHost` to avoid passing messages around. It
  is now simply a container responsible for holding temporary bound
  objects and their associated sockets.

  - Entirely reworks `Server` implementation. The server now only
  handles messages that are directed to it. The service bound objects it
  contains register themselves on the sockets of the server.

Change-Id: Ic9ffaeb6bfefd828017ef4c710c77da89630f6c8
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94731
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
objects: Removes old `BoundObject` and renames `ServiceBoundObject` into `BoundObject`.

`BoundObject`s were always `ServiceBoundObject`s and in some places
in the code, it was assumed to be the case. `BoundObject` was also
empty.

This patch removes the old `BoundObject` type in favor of
the `ServiceBoundObject` class renamed into `BoundObject` and clarifies the name
of some types (such as `BoundAnyObject` which was in fact a `shared_ptr<BoundObject>`
which is now a `shared_ptr<BoundObject>` named `BoundObjectPtr`).

Change-Id: I54b9112767168626c757762d034369a716b9a29c

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
messaging: Replaces use of `StreamContext*` by `MessageSocketPtr`.

`StreamContext*` was used to access the shared capabilities in
deserialization and as keys for remote references in `ObjectHost`. In a
future commit, `ObjectHost` will be rewritten and will need to handle
the lifetime of the `StreamContext/MessageSocket` objects through the
`shared_ptr`s owning them.

This patch replaces all occurences of `StreamContext*` by
`MessageSocketPtr` in message serialization/deserialization so that when
an object is deserialized, it can be assigned to its host and associated
to a `MessageSocket`.

It also removes the `Message::appendValue` method that was declared but
never defined.

Change-Id: Ib5bdfcb0e47bcbdb34b962812163b920b88500c9
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94729

The signature of `GenericProperty::set` was deceptive as it returned a
`FutureSync`, while its implementation was blocking until this
`FutureSync` was set. This resulted in a synchronous behavior.
`GenericProperty::set` is now really asynchronous.
