data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
qi.messaging: Improves performance of message dispatching to objects. #42553

Currently the dispatching system passes a message to all `RemoteObject`
instances registered in the socket's `MessageDispatcher`, recursively.
This change:

- adds a return value to the message handlers to signal if the message have
  been handled or not, with or without errors;
- stops the dispatching of a message as soon as one handler signals that it
  has handled the message (even if it resulted in an error);
- replaces `MessageDispatcher` internals to use a flat-map of `std::function`
  instead of a `std::map` of `qi::Signal` to improve the dispatching process;
- forces `MessageDispatcher` to take an executor that will be used to launch
  each message dispatching - currently using a strand for all dispatching
  for the same socket.

Change-Id: Ib46d2f7e5491f4a7d488b8a04f2dc91e2c2dcc6a
Signed-off-by: Joël LAMOTTE <jlamotte@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94369
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: julien.bernard <julien.bernard@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.messaging: Adds tests for message dispatching. #42553

These tests compare the duration of a call to a non-service object,
vs. the same call but when there are a lot of remote objects stored
in the caller process.
The goal is to make obvious the issue of message dispatching duration
taking more time when a lot of `RemoteObject` are persisted in the
process having the socket receiving the message.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
tests: Replaces duration subtypes by native integers in exposed functions in test_call.

Duration types are converted to integers representing nanoseconds in
messages. It is incorrect to call a function expecting for example
MilliSeconds by passing it an integer and expecting it to be considered
as milliseconds, as it will be instead be considered as nanoseconds.

Example: Failing to call a method that exposes MilliSeconds argument
         correctly.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
void foo(qi::MilliSeconds dura);
...
obj.call<void>("foo", 500); // 500 here will not mean 500 milliseconds,
                            // but 500 nanoseconds converted to milliseconds
                            // which is 0 millisecond.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Change-Id: Ia9788d63dde5c0743adf2a5158d23955b9cde33d
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/93749
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: julien.bernard <julien.bernard@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@softbankrobotics.com>

tools: Rewrites the wireshark dissector for the Qi messaging protocol.

The dissector is now capable of dissecting multiple Qi messages in a
single TCP packet and a Qi message splitted in multiple TCP packets.

It also enhances the way wireshark displays the dissected informations
for example by providing better description of message fields or
by dissecting each bit of the flag bitfield.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
appsession: Fixes incorrect impl of configuration creation.

Fixes #43902, #43895 and partially #43903.

The implementation of `finalizeConfig` was incorrect and would sometimes
fail to complete URLs depending on the default config/environment/CLI args
combination of parameters.

This patch reworks the implementation of the method, declares it in new
header/source so that it can be tested more easily and renames it
`reconfigureWithProgramOptions`.

It adds a lot more tests for it and removes
"test_applicationsession_opts" tests that were less complete and harder
to launch and automatize.

It refactors how the environment variables for `ApplicationSession` are
parsed by using `boost::program_options`.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.functional: Adds function and action composition with `|`.

The traditional mathematical order of function composition is represented by
`*` in `ka`: `g * f` is a function applying `f` then `g`.

It is sometimes easier to read composition from left to right. Therefore, `|`
is identical to `*` except that argument order is reversed: `f | g` is a
function that applies `f` then `g`.

This applies to function composition as well as action composition.

Change-Id: I3439200323bfff78be5e59423bc5c91f32763387
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/92405
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

ka.functional: Splits composition operators in two separate namespaces.

Composition operators for functions and accumulations were in the same
namespace `ka::functional_ops`. Thus, different operators were used for
function composition and for accumulation composition (respectively, `*` and
`*=`).

`*=` has a different precedence level than `*`, which is problematic. Since it
is rare to use both operators at the same time, `*=` has been moved in a
separate `ka::functional_ops_accu` namespace and renamed `*`.

Change-Id: I12a1fbb4c2a9111026a7a8895a534a62ddd05640

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka: Adds a unit type and the associated constant.

`unit_t` is a regular type that conveys no information.
`unit` is the only value of this type.

It can be used in place of `void`, with the benefit of acting as a regular
type (storable in data structures, comparable, etc.), and thus avoiding
`void` specialization in generic code.

Theoretically, it corresponds to the terminal object in the category of
sets and functions, which is the empty set. It also happens to be
(isomorphic to) the product of no set, hence the definition as an
empty tuple.

See <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unit_type>

Change-Id: I2d9ce7a09a4edf60c404fb954fe9a794edca33c1

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.messaging: Changes the call to `service` in `waitForService`.

The call to `Session_Service::service` in `Session::waitForServiceImpl`
was unneeded and too heavy for its use.

To construct a service object, we need at least 3 RPC:
  - A call to the ServiceDirectory to get the information of the service
  (endpoints, id, etc).
  - A request to connect/authentify on the service.
  - A call to get the meta object of the service object.

But in the case of `waitForService`, we just need to check if the
service already exists, so we can just ask the service directory and stop
after step 1. Therefore this patch replaces the service object request
to a call to `ServiceDirectoryClient::service`.

Change-Id: I1710a46b096f855f7095c4501b1147f2e2d686e5
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94587
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
qi.messaging: Fixes data race in `Session::service`.

When called concurrently, Session::service could end up trigerring
multiple service requests for the same service, because we did not lock
the request mutex in Session_Service between the moment we checked for
an existing request and the moment the request was saved.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka: Adds the `ka::empty` function.

Defines the `ka::empty` function that is, amongst other, part of the
`EmptyMutable` concept. This function is defined for:

- raw pointers (a pointer is 'empty' if it is null)
- std::unique_ptr, std::shared_ptr, boost::shared_ptr (in `memory.hpp`)
- boost::optional (in `opt.hpp`)
- any type that defines a member function `empty` (in this case `ka::empty`
  simply forwards to the member function).

`ka::empty` is defined as a polymorphic *function object*, that calls a free
function `empty` through `ADL`. The benefits of this approach are that:

- the caller always write `ka::empty` (no `using ka::empty` needed) while
  ADL is still triggered.
- as a function object, `ka::empty` is easy to manipulate (as a member in
  another type, through function composition, etc.), in contrast to a template
  function.

The general approach is taken from Eric Niebler:
http://ericniebler.com/2014/10/21/customization-point-design-in-c11-and-beyond/

Change-Id: I355596fb44822d554af5460d3fa1566d4dc1de3b
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/93512
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
qi.messaging: Increases `QI_MAX_MESSAGE_PAYLOAD` default value.

This change is motivated by recent needs to transfert bigger `qi::Buffer`
objects.

This is *not* the best way to transfer big data. See `qicore/qi::FilePtr` for
a good alternative.
However, we realise that this limitation is an artificial pessimisation
and is not really useful in practice (nor does it help prevening DOS
attacks).

It is also better to let the user decide what is a reasonable maximum
message size for their use case instead of imposing an artificial limit
in the networking libary.
Therefore, we plan to remove this payload limit in the future.

Change-Id: I6e7fbb585023a7829e845ddc6863c1833d42f323
Signed-off-by: Joël LAMOTTE <jlamotte@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94430
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
qi.eventloop: Catches and logs exceptions when spawning threads fails. #43512

When creating a thread throws, we log an error and skip the creation
for the "grace period". This is to avoid the whole application to crash
in the situation where the system doesn't allow acquiring the resources
to create the thread. In this case, the application can still run with
the already allocated threads.
If the issue is triggered by memory exhaustion, the application will
probably crash at the next allocation anyway.

Change-Id: Ib15643e51eda6afb2a3044709a95406effb12008
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94421

data.message:
ka.functional: Makes some `scopelock` overloads take const-refs.

Overloads of the scopelock function for `weak_ptr` and
`synchronized_value` may take const references because they do not
mutate their parameter.

Among other things, it allows us to have `const scope_lock_proc` for
`weak_ptr`.

data.author: gvallat
data.message:
TypeInfo: Uses boost::type_index instead of std::type_info #43651

On some platforms we can not rely on std::type_info (due to known
implementation limitations). boost::type_index is a reliable replacement.
See the boost documentation for an exact description of the issues: 
https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_64_0/doc/html/boost_typeindex.html#boost_typeindex.motivation

Libqi type interface mechanism relied on std::type_info. As a consequence
it was broken on some platforms (for example, on android-arm64 with
the clang toolchain).

Change-Id: I2f43fcb355ea194ad6ab44f042693ccc4ec3e445
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94291
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.typetraits: Adds `EnableIfInputIterator` and `EnableIfNotInputIterator`.

Causes a substitution failure if the type is not an input iterator, effectively
discarding the function for the overload set.

Note: `EnableIfInputIterator` is to be typically used in conjunction with
      `EnableIfNotInputIterator`.

Example: Making an overload visible only for input iterators, and another
         one for other types.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/// InputIterator I
template<typename I, typename = ka::EnableIfInputIterator<I>>
I distance(I b, I e);

/// Arithmetic N
template<typename N, typename = ka::EnableIfNotInputIterator<N>>
N distance(N b, N e);
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Change-Id: Idaf031bc9863f93bbdee113a03f6ecc703cfba12
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/92391
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: matthieu.paindavoine <matthieu.paindavoine@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.opt: Adds an `std::optional`-like type that handles `void`.

Contains a value or nothing.

This type is similar to `std::optional` but has two distinctive features:

1) It has a `void` specialization that strives to make generic programming
   easier.

2) It is a standard sequence (containing at most one element)

Due to the exceptional nature of `void` amongst C++ types, the API
of this type is slightly different than the one of `std::optional` (see
below).

Basic usage
===========

Example: Setting a value in a non-`void` `opt_t`
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
opt_t<int> o;
o.set(1);
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Example: Setting a value in a `void` `opt_t`
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
opt_t<void> o;
o.set();
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

In the above examples, `set` is used instead of `=` because there is no
way to assign a void value (except by calling `operator=()` directly,
which defeat the readability purpose of operators...).

Complex usage: generic code
===========================

Problem
-------

In generic code, we often want to call an arbitrary procedure and put its
result in an optional. The problem is the procedure might return `void`.
Consider the following example:

Example: Conditionally calling a procedure and returning an `opt_t`
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
// KO: THIS WON'T COMPILE (SEE BELOW)

// Procedure<Ret (Args...)> Proc
template<typename Proc, typename... Args>
auto exec_conditionally(Proc proc, Args const&... args)
  -> decltype(opt_t<decltype(proc(args...))>) // simplification: should decay
{
  opt_t<decltype(proc(args...))> opt;

  // Some pre-processing...

  if (/* Some condition */) {
    opt.set(proc(args...)); // KO if `proc(args...)` returns `void`
  }

  // Some post-processing...
  return opt;
}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

In the above example, if the procedure returns `void` the code won't
compile. This is because the following code is unfortunately illegal:

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
void f(int) { // returns `void`
  // ...
}

bool g() { // takes `void`
  // ...
}

// On call site.
g(f(1)); // KO: doesn't compile.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Solution
--------

Consequently, a dedicated method is provided for this case.

Example: Conditionally calling a procedure and returning an `opt_t`
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
// OK: THIS COMPILES

// Procedure<Ret (Args...)> Proc
template<typename Proc, typename... Args>
auto exec_conditionally(Proc proc, Args const&... args)
  -> decltype(opt_t<decltype(proc(args...))>) // simplification: should decay
{
  opt_t<decltype(proc(args...))> opt;

  // Some pre-processing...

  if (/* Some condition */) {
    opt.call_set(proc, args...); // ok: handles the `void` case
  }

  // Some post-processing...
  return opt;
}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Sequence
========

An optional can be viewed as a sequence whose maximum size is one.
Consequently sequence operations that would make the size exceed one will
throw an exception.
`opt_t` models the standard concept `SequenceContainer` and this notably
allows the use of all standard algorithms.

`Container` methods include:
- iterator methods: begin, end, cbegin...
- size methods: empty, size...
- swap

`SequenceContainer` methods include:
- insert methods: constructor taking ranges, insert, emplace, push_back...
- erase methods: erase, clear, pop_back...
- accessors: [], at, front, back...

TODO: Simplify the implementation by using a `boost::static_vector` when
it is stable (see https://svn.boost.org/trac10/ticket/11957 and
https://github.com/boostorg/container/issues/78).

Change-Id: Ia83c9eefd1a277bbc5943e5537ac99431af99073
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/90490
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: matthieu.paindavoine <matthieu.paindavoine@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

- Replaces C's `rand()` and `seed()` by C++ `<random>` library;
- Uses default random generator with system's random device instead of
  relying on `time_since_epoch()`;
- Uses 8 random binary blocks (from system's random device) as seed
  to obtain a good entropy;

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
uuid: Improves cryptographical quality of our internal uuid generator.

"Quality" here is the "quality of randomness" as described on wikipedia:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptographically_secure_pseudorandom_number_generator

In Boost 1.64 (which is the currently supported version),
the default Boost.UUID random generator uses a Mersenne Twister generator
whose randomness is not considered "cryptographically secure".
This change replaces that random generator by Boost.Random's
`random_device` which is guaranteed (per the documentation) to be a
cryptographically secure random source (of the system).


Change-Id: I007191f1cb7c4aa05c8efaa5a3dd06e415947f0e
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94746
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
type: Reworks conversion between optionals.

This patch deprecates functions from the API of AnyReference/AnyValue.

This patch:

- refactors the behavior of the conversion between optionals in the type system.

- enables the conversion from `Opt<AnyValue>` to `Opt<U>` if `Opt<AnyValue>` has
  no value or if it has a value convertible to `U`.

- makes the `AnyReferenceBase::setOptional` method take a
  `boost::optional<AnyReference>` for consistency with the other similar methods
  of this interface.

- introduces new tests of conversion when a method taking an optional as
  parameter is exposed and called.

Change-Id: Ic1db66ed92e49bc1465a01515ad9a53fa87b6f87

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.eventloop: Adds a dynamic shrinking mechanism.

General explanation
=====================

Up to now, the behavior of the threadpool was to spawn threads on contention.
These threads were never destroyed. Having a temporary burst of activity
(typically at startup) would later result in a lot of idle threads, causing an
unjustified increase of cpu load. The threadpool now terminates threads that
have been idle for too long.

Environment variables
=====================

The maximum idle duration is controlled by the environment variable
`QI_EVENTLOOP_THREAD_MAX_IDLE_DURATION` (in milliseconds, like the other
eventloop environment variables).

It is also possible to specify a minimum number of threads with the environment
variable `QI_EVENTLOOP_MIN_THREAD_COUNT`. This allows to limit the shrinking
mechanism, even if the threads are idle. A `setMinThreads` method is available
on `Eventloop` too.

Technical details
=====================

The infamous "ping thread" was responsible for spawning new threads in case of
contention. It is now, on top of that, responsible for terminating idle threads.
Each thread is now associated to a last task run date. The "ping task"
(periodically launched by the "ping thread" to check contention) now checks if
this date for the current worker thread is too far in the past. If it is, a
specific exception is launched that causes the termination of this worker
thread. The general behavior of the threadpool is that if it has too many
threads, they are bound to sooner or later run this ping task and therefore to
be terminated.

Change-Id: Ieb9eddbe8c35a87b39b12bd04ae7871a3635d2bb
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94133
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
strand: Changes order of actions when joining.

When joining the strand, we waited for the end of the currently
executing task before setting scheduled and deferred tasks futures in
error.

This could result in a deadlock if a stranded task was waiting for the
result of another stranded task when the strand was joined.

We now set scheduled and deferred tasks futures in error before waiting
for the current task to finish.

This patch also refactors the test
"TestStrand.JoinStrandEndsRunningAsyncFutureInError" because it was
racy and could easily deadlock. In consequence, it got renamed to
"TestStrand.JoinStrandEndsScheduledTaskInError".

Change-Id: I4eb40467a377d7a32bfd901d4ddd4d6edbd9f604
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94404
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
Adds ObjectUid as universal ID of remote objects implemented using PtrUid.

This change removes the implication that we are exposing pointers
in qi::Object interface through qi::Object::ptruid().
We deprecate qi::Object::ptruid() and provide qi::Object::uid() as
a clearer replacement.
The implementation still relies on ObjectUid to have the interface
and be compatible with PtrUid but we can now separate the meaning
of an unique identifier of an object refered by qi::Object from an
universally unique pointer value that PtrUid represents,
allowing for ObjectUid to be implemented differently in the future
and to clarify the role of qi::Object::uid().

Change-Id: I3fdc96ad9a545d505b6f7c65f93190c74ed026b6
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94337
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Victor Paleologue
data.message:
strand: Fixes data races on destruction and joining qi::Strand. #43730

 - Adds test demonstrating a crash when destroying strand after
   calling `qi::Strand::asyncDelay`.
 - Fixes data race in `qi::Strand::~Strand` and `qi::Strand::join` when
   multiple threads can call `qi::Strand::join`.
 - Fixes memory corruption of the `qi::StrandPrivate` object because
   of misuse of `boost::atomic_exchange`.
 - Promises of tasks passed to `qi::Strand::asyncDelay` are now tracked
   and set in error if we are joining before they have been queued
   in the strand (after the delay) to avoid the related future to not
   be set until the delay is passed (that can happen a long time after
   the strand is joined).
 - Removed some unnecessary sharing of the `qi::StrandPrivate` object
   by wrapped tasks, replaced by weak sharing.
 - Adds logs when joining strands.

Change-Id: I345664d65aedb14c50989508a3017ad62322ad86

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
macro: Adds the `QI_API_TESTONLY` macro.

The `QI_API_TESTONLY` macro exports/imports types when compiling tests only.
This is for instance useful to unit-test internal components of libqi.

This macro definition depends on the `QI_WITH_TESTS` macro.

Note: `QI_WITH_TESTS` is currently defined by
[qiBuild](http://doc.aldebaran.com/qibuild/advanced/cmake/api/tests.html?highlight=qi_with_tests).

Example: Making an internal type available for unit testing.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
class QI_API_TESTONLY StuffPrivate
{
  ...
};
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Note: Any type to export must be prefixed with `QI_API_TESTONLY`, which may be
unconvenient. A better solution could be to export all types when compiling
tests.

Change-Id: I109ded0a33055e192a83a19cc605cfb1882eac3b
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94221

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
messaging: Fixes a data race in ServiceDirectoryProxy.

A race could occur when a service was registered on the proxy, which
triggerred a mirroring to the service directory. As this takes time,
if the service was then unregistered in the meantime, the proxy would
get the event of registration from the service directory, check on its
session if the service existed (which wouldn't because it would just got
removed) and would then proceed mirroring the service that it mirrored
back to the service directory. The service would then not be
unregistered from the service directory.

           Server                       Service
Client     Session          Proxy       Directory
──────     ───────          ─────       ─────────
  ┊ Register  ┊               ┊             ┊
  ┊ service   ┊               ┊             ┊
  ┃──────────>┊               ┊             ┊
  ┃           ┃┄┄┐            ┊             ┊
  ┃<──────────┊  ┆Service     ┊             ┊
  ┊           ┊  ┆registered  ┊             ┊

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
buffer: Removes memory pool.

The pool was never shrunk, resulting in ever increasing memory. This problem
is particularly salient in case of isolated message bursts.

It may also get worse system-wise due to the existence of independent libqi
instances in distinct processes.

Another potential aggravating factor (not addressed by this patch) is that each
buffer is currently ~768 bytes long at least, which may have a negative impact
on memory in case of a small message burst. This lead can also be explored.

This patch must be tested in real context to prove its value.

This is to mitigate issues #43516 and #43454.

Change-Id: I9e03ec0f3dbc70be7ca1bca14db617ef6775938a
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/94091
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
signal: Optimizes memory usage in subscribers.

Before this patch, any subscriber using an execution context made a copy of the
arguments, in order to post to the execution context. This patch avoids this by
making a unique copy if needed.

This is to mitigate issues #43516 and #43454.

data.author: Sébastien Barthélémy
data.message:
simplify default log handler creation #43363

qiLog was initially designed to have a single "default log handler",
with SubscriberId == 0, created automatically when libqi initializes
the global variables.
Accordingly, many qi::log functions take a SubscriberId as an *optional*
parameter, with 0 as the default value, referring to the default log
handler.

But more "automatically created" log handlers were later added to libqi
on some platforms. Handlers are also added automatically by libqi-java
and qilaunch.

Here are the automatically added handlers on each platform (1 if the
handler is automatically added, 0 if not).

handler                robot    linux    windows  mac      android
=====================  =======  =======  =======  =======  =======
console (to stdout)    1        1        1        1        0
journald               1        1/0      0        0        0       # ifdef WITH_SYSTEMD
android                0        0        0        0        1
windowsdebuggeroutput  0        0        1        0        0       # (logs discarded if not running)
jni                    na       na       na       na       1       # added by libqi-java
remote/listener        1        1        1        1        na      # added by qilaunch
=====================  =======  =======  =======  =======  =======

It brings several problems:

* inconsistent "automatic" behavior depending on platforms and compilation
  options

* limited control on the verbosity and filtering rules used by the
  automatically added handlers: they all share the same

* resource waste and log duplication. For instance, logs of any qilaunch
  process are triplicated on robots.

* standard output pollution for CLI programs (like qicli)

With this commit, we change this behavior:

libqi will create at most one log handler automatically, instructed
by the QI_DEFAULT_LOGHANDLER environment variable, as follow:

* if QI_DEFAULT_LOGHANDLER==none, no log handler
  is automatically registered by libqi.
  Notice that log handlers may still be added by qilaunch, libqi-java or
  the application code, but they may miss the early logs.

* if QI_DEFAULT_LOGHANDLER==stdout, the logs are written to stdout
  (using consoleloghandler). Notice that on Android platform stdout is
  usually redirected to /dev/null.

* if QI_DEFAULT_LOGHANDLER==logger, the logs are written to the
  system-wide logger. Currently supported are linux's journald and
  android's log output.

* if QI_DEFAULT_LOGHANDLER==debugger, the logs are written to a
  debugging facility. Currently only Windows' debug output is
  implemented.

* if QI_DEFAULT_LOGHANDLER=="" or is not defined, the behavior depends
  on the platform and on compilation options:

  * it behaves as if "logger" was given on android and on linux,
    if libqi was compiled with systemd support

  * it behaves as is "stdout" was given on mac OS, Windows, and
    linux if libqi was compiled without systemd support.

* if QI_DEFAULT_LOGHANDLER has an unsupported value, or if adding the
  handler fails, no fallback is performed:
  no log handler is registered by libqi, as if "none" was given,
  but an error message is sent to stderr.

Change-Id: I8b016e9bf12837fee25aafe5e270135157b441ad
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/91966
Reviewed-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: philippe.martin <philippe.martin@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: sbarthelemy <sbarthelemy@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.os: Modifies conditional definitions of PTRDIFF_MIN and PTRDIFF_MAX to be self-sufficient.

`PTRDIFF_MIN` and `PTRDIFF_MAX` may not be defined on some platforms (e.g.
android arm32). As a first step we define the values by hard-coding them, to
avoid relying on another constant. This guarantees that it will work whatever
the presence or absence of other constants (INT32_MAX, etc.).

TODO: Remove this when alternatively
 - qibuild is modified to generate a libqi user CMakeLists.txt that defines
   correct constants (`#define __STDC_LIMIT_MACROS`)
 - Android NDK is upgraded to use at least Android API level 21.

The used constants values are taken from the Android NDK file
'platforms/android-21/arch-arm/usr/include/stdint.h'.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.socket: Makes message to send passed by value.

Due to some protocol extensions (e.g. direct message dispatch), code internal
to `TcpMessageSocket` may need to modify the message to send. Until now, the
message to send was passed by const reference, so it was not modifiable by
`TcpMessageSocket`.

The existing libqi calls to `TcpMessageSocket::send` have been modified to move
the message, therefore there should be no performance impact.

Change-Id: Ib0781af303c87cedafe7f49db64d51500786c7f9
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/92601

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.socket: Forwards the received message as non-const inside socket code.

Due to some protocol extensions (e.g. direct message dispatch), it may now be
needed in `TcpMessageSocket` to modify the received message. Until now, the
received message was internally forwarded as a const reference, so it was not
modifiable by `TcpMessageSocket`.

Note that the message is still passed as a const-reference to upper layers, so
that libqi's code is not impacted.

data.author: Matthieu Paindavoine
data.message:
genericObject: Plugs memory leak.

Ensures that the shared_ptr is reset upon destruction of the
corresponding GenericObject. Replaces original function by a lambda
because it was only called in one place.

The memory leak occured because the previous deleter kept a copy of the
shared pointer of the Proxy. If the deleter was kept alive by a weak
pointer (eg WeakObject), then the shared pointer may never be
destroyed. The lifetime of the shared pointer of the Proxy is then
linked to the lifetime of the deleter and thus linked to the last weak
pointer lifetime, which is incorrect.

Fixes #41451

Change-Id: I4f1b5f9cf3de64af42837ca884fa93c1927e9e57
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/91300
Reviewed-by: matthieu.paindavoine <matthieu.paindavoine@softbankrobotics.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
qi.anyobject: Simplifies and makes safer `metaCall` (#34829)

When a meta-call is asynchronous, it posts a `MFunctorCall` function object to
the eventloop. `MFunctorCall` took a raw pointer on a promise and deleted it on
its first call. It didn't subsequently set the promise pointer to null. Thus,
another call would result in a crash. On the other hand, no call would result
in a memory leak. This implementation was therefore highly unsafe and brittle.

`Promise` behaving as a shared pointer, there is no point passing a raw pointer
anymore, and `MFunctorCall` takes now a plain promise instead.

Beware that the operational behavior of `MFunctorCall` has changed, as now the
promise's resource is not freed on first call, but rather when there the last
copy of an instance is destroyed. This could paradoxically lead to a memory
leak if the `libqi` keeps these objects too long (i.e. in a "mysterious" cache,
etc.).

Change-Id: I0be0872e2c1313074dd3019b24de8c43b120168b
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/91550
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Miriam Bilac
data.message:
Fixes ptrUid lost when using impl types with QI_REGISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_H

QI_REGISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_H associates an interface type to an
implementation type that might be unrelated. However,
not like QI_REGISTER_IMPLEMENTATION (note the absence of `_H`),
QI_REGISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_H generates special proxy types wrapping
the real implementation object.

When using QI_REGISTER_IMPLEMENTATION_H and doing:

    Object<Interface> obj{ make_shared<Impl> }; // Will instantiate wrapper

then the Object constructor detects this situation as a special case
and instantiates the appropriate wrapper type then put the real
implementation object in it.
In the process, the ptrUid of the real objet is lost (without this patch)
when creating the GenericObject associated to this wrapper+impl couple,
but it is still the real object being called in the end.

In this change we are making sure that we provide the real implementation
ptrUId instead of creating a new one based on the wrapper object
when making the associated GenericObject.

Change-Id: Iedca59079d4d2f199517e332a4fd4bd96a538057
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/91604
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
type: Adds missing handling of ptruid in proxy objects.

In cases where we use interfaces and proxies, the proxy object
were not built with the ptruid value of the original object,
leading to inconsistencies in comparisons.
This change fixes that by passing the ptruid value
all the way to the point we build the proxy object.

data.message:
concurrency: Adds execution options when calling methods on ExecutionContext impls.

- Adds `ExecutionOptions` that will contain options to change the
   default behaviour of `ExecutionContext` implementations.
- Adds `CancelOption` enum to allow specifying if a task should or not
   be executed if scheduled in an `ExecutionContext`
   but have been cancel-requested.
   The default behaviour is to not execute that task.
   This option allows to change the behaviour.
- Implemented handling of `ExecutionOptions` in `ExecutionContext`
   implementations (`Strand` and `EventLoop`).

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.scoped: Removes move-assignment.

A correct move-assignment must call the function of the target `scoped_t`
before performing the assignment by itself. This is not currently done.

Doing so means that a default-constructed `scoped_t` that is moved to will have
its function called. But there is no way to know if this default constructed
function is valid or not (the `Regular` concept does not give this guarantee,
as it relies on the notion of 'partially-formed state' for default-constructed
values).

Solutions do exist to distinguish valid default constructed values from invalid
ones (by introducing a tag type, etc.), but they hurt the design simplicity of
`scoped_t`.

Consequently, move-assignment is now deleted. Users that want to
default-construct a `scoped_t` must wrap it in an optional.

Change-Id: I471d0db9d191975572ed6c9f5b94f64e53ec90b2
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/90640
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.typetraits: Removes sub-namespace `traits`.

`ka` naming convention makes non-ambiguous the difference between
metaprogramming entities (type functions, concepts) and the other ones
(variables, functions, types), making superfluous the need for a separate
namespace. This results in code in a better ratio signal / noise.

Formatting
==========

Kind of entity                                     Formatting
---------------                                    -----------
non-metaprogramming (types, functions, variables)  snake_case
metaprogramming (type functions, concepts)         CamelCase

Example
==========

Kind of entity   Examples
---------------  ---------------
variable         i, x, proc, rng
function         is_regular, scoped, erase_if
type             constant_function_t, scoped_t, mutable_store_t
type function    RemovePointer, Decay, EnableIf
concept          Regular, Transformation, Isomorphism, Range

Change-Id: I6523f537b99f0054fee16b630b8c0a24bb6ba4a8

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
future: Adds safer alternatives to `value()`.

`value()` returns a reference to a constant.
As such, this reference must not outlive the `Future` it comes from.
It is however easy in compositional code to end up with a dangling reference.

New safer alternatives are now:

- manipulating a copy of the value, returned by `valueCopy()`

- extending a `Future`'s lifetime by manipulating a `shared_ptr` returned by
  `valueSharedPtr()`

The original `value()` is neither changed nor deprecated, as it can be more
performant, provided the user takes the responsibility of the lifetime issue.

Change-Id: Iaea9b1a2517a02a3dc0bb70e67f70ee36836f2ba
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/90128
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.functional: Adds `const` versions and homogenizes naming.

The naming rules that were enforced are:

Naming
======

- types end with "_t"
  (eg. `constant_function_t`)

- constructor functions are named from their type without "_t"
  (eg. `constant_function` constructs a `constant_function_t`, performing
  type deduction)

- function objects are polymorphic by default, so no need to state it in the name
  (e.g `incr_t` is polymorphic)

- function objects that are monomorphic must state it in their name
  (e.g. `incr_mono_t` is monomorphic)

Modifications
-------------

Before                 After
-------                ------
poly_constant_function constant_function_t
no_op_procedure        constant_function_t<void>
id_transfo             id_transfo_t
id_action              id_action_t
composition            composition_t
composition_accu       composition_accu_t
data_bound_proc        data_bound_proc_t
incr                   incr_mono_t
decr                   decr_mono_t
poly_incr              incr_t
poly_decr              decr_t

`const` modifications
=====================

existing `operator()` made `const`
-----------------------------------
id_action_t

`const` `operator()` added
---------------------------
composition_t
composition_accu_t
data_bound_proc_t
data_bound_transfo_t
apply_t
scope_lock_proc_t

non-`const` `operator()` added
-------------------------------
scope_lock_transfo_t

Change-Id: Ie6776d46e455dafc58761febd6c399e949f29d72
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/90453
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ka.macro: Adds macros to derive (i.e. generate) "constructor functions".

Constructor functions are functions like `std::make_tuple` that are
semantically identical to a real constructor, except that they are easier to
deal with due to type deduction.

Example: Deriving a "constructor function" for a template type.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
template<typename T, typename U>
struct my_stuff_t {
  // `my_stuff_t` is constructible from a `T` and a `U`.
  ...
};

KA_DERIVE_CTOR_FUNCTION_TEMPLATE(my_stuff)

// In user code:
auto x = my_stuff(5, true); // `x` has type `my_stuff_t<int, bool>`
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

For consistency, an equivalent macro is provided for non-template types.

Change-Id: Id3169aff518bb79d52e8ee89761d707b1a250db9
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/90452
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: matthieu.paindavoine <matthieu.paindavoine@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
cmake.tests: Installs libtestsession even with QI_WITH_TESTS=OFF.

Some projects use libtestsession for their own tests while using libqi
from the toolchain. The package qi-framework which includes libqi
is compiled without the tests (QI_WITH_TESTS=OFF) when it's compiled
for the toolchain which prevents having libtestsession available in
the toolchain package.

This patch is a workaround to that problem. A more long-term solution
would be to move libtestsession and all it includes inside libqi.

messaging: Changes default listening IP to localhost #41381

Services and executables should not by default listen on all interfaces,
only gateways are allowed to listen for remote connections. This patch
makes sure that by default, sessions in libqi will listen only on
localhost.

To achieve this, this patch changes the default listen URL in
ApplicationSession and also the URL a session will start (on its own ...)
listening to when a service is registered on it.

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
messaging: Adds capability "ObjectPtrUID" for protocol retro-compatibility.

Without this capability, a process that was not compiled with PtrUID
but communicating with a process compiled with PtrUID will receive
messages with unhandled data that it will still attempt to read and
will end with incorrect data.

Adding the capability makes both process know if the ptruid will be
sent and receive or not. When a process A can handle ptruid but not another
process B, A will create a new ptruid for the received object.

Change-Id: Iefed74ac95b2cf3d03b3ac7d61f37f0fe81212d0

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
ptruid: Changes definition of `end()` to avoid dereferencing an invalid iterator.

Context:

`PtrUid` stores data as a `std::array` of `uint32_t`. This makes copying,
comparing, and other operations more efficient than if a `std::array` of
`uint8_t` was used.

Nevertheless, it is sometimes useful for the user to be able to iterate on
bytes rather than on `uint32_t`s. `PtrUid` therefore also provides `uint8_t`
iterators. The definition of the `uint8_t` version of `end()` reused the
`uint32_t` version and was implemented as:
`static_cast<uint8_t*>(&*endUInt32())`.

It is not legal to dereference an 'end' iterator. In this case it is unlikely
to cause a problem since it should be optimized by the compiler. But it does
make debug tools complain.

The implementation of `uint8_t` `end()` was changed to: `begin() + offset`.

Change-Id: I437a4b263bbdeffda4af80862201021b2b82c470
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/89457
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: matthieu.paindavoine <matthieu.paindavoine@softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Strand: Adds a `join()` that does not throw exception. (#40323)

This `join` returns an optional error message.

- In case an exception is thrown in the internal code of `join()`, it is
  catched and its message is returned.

- Otherwise, an empty error message is returned.

Example: Preventing a destructor to throw exceptions because of `join`.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
~MyActor() {
  if (const auto error = _strand.join(std::nothrow)) {
    qiLogWarning() << "Error while joining the strand. Detail: " << *error;
  }
}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Change-Id: I07bdc1627ac7995c7c16fa34fe0ddc49dd80a77a

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Object: Makes conversion to boolean explicit.

This is to avoid unwanted conversions from `Object` to `bool` and thus get a
better type-safety.

Implicit conversion to `bool` was unintendly used in unit tests, specifically
in the expressions `ostream << obj`. Despite the lack of `operator<<` for
`Object`, this compiled because of the implicit conversion from `Object` to
`bool`. A dummy `operator<<` for `Object` has been added in unit tests to
compensate (see `objectio.hpp`).

Change-Id: I041727375899e597709d94954b1a53980d61ef42

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Equality now works even if objects travel through the network.

Until now, equality of Objects was equality of their pointers, so if an object
was sent to a service and returned, it would not be equal to the original
object anymore.
An object id is in fact a hash on the pointer passed to the object at the time
of its creation. This hash is a sha1 hash on the concatenation of the machine
uuid, the process uuid and the pointer value. An uuid is used for the process
instead of the process id to avoid different pointers at different times having
the same hash due to process id recycling.
A debug mode also exists where the first number of PtrUid is deterministic
(i.e. it doesn't change at each executions).

Change-Id: I941f67542b9114950bf2e97ef89723caebdeeb18
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/89024
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
tools: Corrects implementation of sha1 and makes it more generic.

The previous implementation relied on `boost::uuids::detail::sha1` but:

1) it is in a `detail` namespace, so not officially supported

2) the produced digests are different from the one of tools such as
`openssl sha1` and `sha1sum` (!).
This is apparently because of a wrong handling of endianness.

data.message:
Future: drop onCancel callback after the first call

This is a user-visible change: the callback will only be called
once, while previously, several calls could have occurred.

Yet, this behaviour is not documented, I suspect changing it is ok.

With the new behaviour, arguments captured by the callback are freed
earlier, which is better, and could avoid shared_ptr loops in some
cases.

data.author: JoÃ«l LAMOTTE
data.message:
Adds a log handler routing logs to the debug output in Visual Studio when a debugger is attached.

This is designed to be useful when debugging several processes in parallel.
For example, when launching a parent process spawning several other processes,
Visual Studio can track the child processes and attach the debugger automatically
to them. However in this case only the qiLog output from the parent process is
visible because it is routed only in the console output.
Displaying all the processes logging in the debug output helps tracking what each
process was logging separately and help compare them in one text block.
To make sure this is useful, the launch command line and PID informations
are added to the formatted log messages in this case.

Change-Id: I8f072642b846050de1c3707f3c86c78cfa18c0a4
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/84717

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
gateway: Added `status` property to clarify the whole gateway status.

The complete status is now provided through one channel the
`status` property, instead of two, `connected` and `listening`.
This is to avoid potential races that happen when
trying to get the values of two properties.
The issue was triggered by our tests.

- fixes tests that neeeded to wait for gateway to be connected
  and listening to a service directory (`Status::isReady()` returns true);
- deprecates property `connected`, replaced by `status`;
- removed property `listening` which was not used,
  also replaced by `status`.

PeriodicTask may recursively try to lock its mutex so this patch
transforms the mutex into a recursive mutex. It also changes the use of

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
messaging: Decorellates Disconnecting state construction from socket closing

Disconnecting state construction also used to schedule a close
on the socket, which meant that we had to lock the _stateMutex
of the TcpMessageSocket during that construction and until
the _state member of the TcpMessageSocket was set which was unwanted.

This patch adds a call operator to Disconnecting which triggers the
close. This allows us to create the new state outside of the lock (since
it has no side effect anymore), lock the mutex, set the _state variable,
unlock the mutex and then only trigger the close.

Change-Id: I3570c44b0d59f68b6afbcb6ad34b1496f7c5817d
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/88217
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
gateway: Fixes crashes related to null pointer members

The members _server and _sdClient of the Gateway class are pointers and
as such, the possibility they are null must be handled.

The problem we had was that while the destructor of GatewayPrivate was
calling the destructor of _server (which is a pointer to Session), some
other methods of the class that used _server could be called at the same
time as signal callbacks.

This patch makes sure that we don't use any of these members when they
are null and also reinforces synchronization between method calls.

Change-Id: I9e71a09fbea889850da8ff20d179d24b84d827aa
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/88218
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>

Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
strand: Executes async callbacks immediately when already in context

When strand is required to execute a function with no delay and the
thread is already in the execution context of the strand, it needs to
execute the function immediately to avoid a deadlock. Until now it
wasn't the case. This patch adds a execNow function in StrandPrivate and
calls it in asyncDelayImpl in the right case.

Change-Id: Ic59f95e5b0830382a16880b6859905acab27e8db

data.author: Victor PALEOLOGUE
data.message:
Future: do not let then and andThen cast the continuation's futures #40589

Until now, there was an implicit cast of the resulting future of the
continuations, producing a warning. This cast was dangerous because it
could block the current thread whereas it was not desired.

Instead of unwrapping the future whenever possible, it was decided that
to let the users of then and andThen decided what results to unwrap, so
that to prevent losing information.

For this reason, in this fix we return the wrapped value, even if it
consists in an API change, breaking the compilation. All parts of libqi
that were broken are fixed in this commit.

As a side effect, the strands won't unwrap the futures anymore. It is also
more coherent. But for qi::bind to keep working a "strandedUnwrapped"
function had to be defined on actors, along with a "unwrappedSchedulerFor"
function on strands.

The need for qi::bind is for deprecated functions only, but it conflicts
with other parts of the code, like trackable.hxx, which need qi::Future
to implement qi::bind!

By putting further away the declarations requiring qi::bind, we allow
trackable to react properly to futures, and make more flexible this
include knot.

Change-Id: I9b732a15421c4508fd64d400a48840948970e791
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/86502
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: vpaleologue <vpaleologue@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: vpaleologue <vpaleologue@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: JoÃ???Ã??Ã?Â«l LAMOTTE
data.message:
tests: Fixes tests not passing because connecting too fast to child process.

Sometimes (mainly on Windows in Debug mode) a child process will take some
time to startup. When a test launches such process and then tries
to connect via a socket to it, a connection error might happen which might make
the test fail while the issue is not related to the test.
To prevent this, we provide test::tryConnect() to attempt several connections
before considering the connection to be failed.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
messaging: Refactors how SslContext is passed to sockets

SslContexts have entity semantics and have to be kept alive through
sockets lifetime. The network code put them in function objects that can
be copied therefore they can't be passed by reference.

The Ssl context was previously put in function objects by using a
`MoveOnCopy`. But this component has the same semantics has the
now-deprecated std::auto_ptr, and is dangerous. We effectively sometimes
ended up with a moved-from ssl context. This patch solves the problem by
now passing the ssl context by shared pointer.

It also refactors some parts of the network code so that it can take any
type that respects NetSslSocket concept (e.g. a
SslSocket<qi::sock::NetworkAsio> or a
SocketWithContext<qi::sock::NetworkAsio>).

Change-Id: I6d88e67acce3c65c83beb63ac19b8fc6f6303d73
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/85223
Reviewed-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Tested-by: vincent.palancher <vincent.palancher@external.softbankrobotics.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: JoÃ?Â«l LAMOTTE
data.message:
tests: Removes dependency to libqi for execs used in "spawn" functions tests.

Spawn functions tests (including ScopedProcess usage)
on Windows can fail because the launched executable fails on
startup as the working environment is incorrect (the executable is in
a temporary directory with no other dependencies)
and the system does not find boost libraries dlls
which are required by libqi.
This is because we do not make the child process inherit the test process environment
when calling the spawn functions.

These executable do not need libqi anyway so removing the dependency
fixes this issue (they can be run standalone).

Change-Id: Id88b12c0a9fe7ad0328e9ee65e0707f76b13918e

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
messaging: Fixes data races in SetupConnectionStop

In the call operator that takes a socket, the call to close()
needs to be wrapped in the io_service strand.
In the call operator that takes a resolver, the lifetime of
the resolver could not be enforced by the caller at the time
the continuation to stop was called.
SetupConnectionStop now takes a syncTransfo and a lifetimeTransfo.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
messaging: Transforms connecting/connected result to shared_ptr

There were cases where the result of the connecting/connected
state could be set to the complete promise before being
modified (eg by a call to stop on the socket), since there can be some
time between the moment we set the complete promise and
the moment the continuations are called which is when
the state is effectivily changed.

Results are now treated as entities and are kept inside
a shared_ptr, protected by a synchronized_value.

they are now initialized to zero.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
network: Changes disconnection by calling shutdown() instead of cancel().

`cancel` cancels any pending operation. But if there is no such operation because
we are currently processing an operation (e.g. a read or a write), the cancel will
result in a no-op and the disconnection of the socket will never happen.
`shutdown` fixes these issues.

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
messaging: lock socket state mutex before disconnecting

Creating a DisconnectingState closes the socket as a side effect.
A race condition would occur if between the time the state was
created and the _stateMutex of the TcpMessageSocket was locked
TcpMessageSocket::send was called. That call would lock the mutex
and check the socket state which would not have been changed yet
although the socket would still be closing. This would lead to a
crash in asio.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
meta: Adds EnableIfNotBaseOf type alias.

Useful to avoid a template constructor to swallow copy constructor,
move constructor, etc.

Example: leaving untouched copy constructor and assignment operator
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  template<typename U, typename = traits::EnableIfNotBaseOf<Mutable, U>>
  explicit Mutable(U&& u)
      : data(std::forward<U>(u))
  {
  }

  template<typename U, typename = traits::EnableIfNotBaseOf<Mutable, U>>
  Mutable& operator=(U&& u)
  {
    data = std::forward<U>(u);
    return *this;
  }
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Change-Id: I44a129307207f148d9fb43f41ee6e176ebfbba84
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/84370

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
Fixes Session::waitForService blocking call.

Session::waitForService call must never block (the user can wait on the
returned future, or not) but it was calling Future::hasError
which is a blocking call.
If the caller get the future and do not wait but do not intend
to wait for the result, the call would block anyway, making
the future useless.

data.author: Igor CESI
data.message:
Fix a bug in stream context's metaobject cache (fix for NAOqi Bug #32745).

The cache never worked because the MetaObject::operator<() was implemented wrongly.
MetaObjects are copied into the cache map and MetaObjectPrivate objects are uniquely
allocated on each copy. Comparing MetaObjectPrivate in this case does not have sense
because no 2 MetaObjects are ever equal.

Fix this by adding SHA1 hash of the MetaObjectPrivate content (function names, signal
names, property names and description are used to calculate the hash). Use this hash
to compare two MetaObjects.

Moved MetaObject unit test from test_object to a new file (test_metaobject) to regroup
all MetaObject tests in one place.

This is an upgraded version of change id I8e3691ef2e91374f4d37491722c872c55e04ea11

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
network: Fixes a potential crash in TransportServerAsioPrivate.

The server must avoid being closed while accepting a connection.
Not making exclusive accepting and closing opens the possibility of this scenario:

TransportServer (thread 0)           TransportServerAsioPrivate (thread 1)
----------------------------------   ---------------------------------------
                                     enters onAccept()
                                     not closed so continues
enters destructor
closes TransportServerAsioPrivate
  (cleanup and closes acceptor)
exits destructor
                                     continues onAccept() and uses the pointer
                                      to the closed TransportServer
                                     Segmentation fault

Change-Id: Iad8a96c55509fb39f14031241123efddfbd187e0

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
Fixes qi::bind compilation: Workaround VS2015 compiler bug.

VS2015 compiler (vc14.0)  might have an incorrect behaviour in expressions mixing `decltype`
feature with either template typedefs (with `using` keyword) or tail return type
which are (all 3) features they implemented recently (but are fixed mostly in vc14.1/vc15, VS2017).

The test added here reproduces one case found by client code which put in evidence this
compiler bug.
The fix is to try to express the same idea but with different features,
here using a template type in a non-template typedef using (instead of a template typedef).

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
socket: Makes connecting state cancelable by short-circuiting the connecting steps. (fix #38450)

In the previous version, the code was taking into account a disconnection request only on state change.
For instance, it waited the end of the connection to effectively start the disconnection steps.
The goal was to have the simplest and most predictible code flow (no shortcut, always the same
succession of states).

It happens that if the server crashes during the client connection, the connection will have to wait
a system timeout to end, and then the disconnection request will be processed. This timeout is
often too long to be acceptable.

In the new version, requesting a disconnection during the connection steps will provoque an immediate
abort of the connection. This solution is clean, because the code flow, in terms of state, does not
change. A cancelled connection will result in the same further states (disconnecting, disconnected).

Change-Id: I34dfdb7438b35b313faea68ef2d46fd136c6d254
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/83000
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Vincent Palancher
data.message:
Threads: sequence BoundObject destruction #38301 #38327

ServiceBoundObject termination removes all objects it contains
and destroys them asynchronously, which can create a massive thread
spawn, hit the max number of threads and deadlock the system
especially in SGW and SD.
This patch adds a test reproducing the problem and sequences
BoundObjects destruction.

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
Fixes QI_NOTHROW macro implementation.

The previous implementation was relying on the C++ macro telling
the supported C++ version. However this is not enough to know if
a specific feature is supported or not by a compiler and should
never be used to detect features. There are other macros in C++14
to check specific features, but the simplest way to do it is to
just rely on Boost's implementation of the same macro.

data.message:
Generic Object: meta call to track the underlying future properly #38551

GenericObject::metaCall's returned future did only track the underlying
call being performed, and did not adapt the future to the underlying call's
returned future. It is now fixed and specified explicitly in the docstring.

This change required that adapting futures of AnyReference was made
possible by changes in futureAdapter, which naturally involve an additional
copy.

The commit include tests proving that it does not work in the direct mode.

data.message:
Property: can be made directly from accessors, with no explicit storage

It covers the cases for read-only and immutable properties cleanly.
For naming and architectural reasons, the other types of properties were
updated:
- a PropertyInterface<T> allows to deal with typed properties whichever
implementation they use
- boost mutex was replaced by std mutex
- documentation was updated
- all functors are given as rvalue-references
- boost non-copyable was replaced by C++11 equivalent
- code in hxx was re-ordered to match the order in hpp
- got rid of useless includes
- renamed the protected fields in PropertyWithStorage for ProxyProperty
access

Change-Id: I79d64d24fda55de27ed214db5312387cda5fd340

data.author: Victor PALEOLOGUE
data.message:
Type: fix crashy conversion of AnyReference from invalid values #37978

The tests revealed many intermediary issues that are only fully fixed
with the last patch in AnyReference:
- the setter defined in the Object type interface had an undefined behavior
when receiving dynamic values with invalid content. Now, the setter throws
if an invalid value is encountered in the source.
- conversion function from AnyReference to object did not handle exceptions
so behaved differently from other conversion functions.
- AnyFunction::call did not properly check the arguments before using them,
and in fact did not support invalid values cleanly. Now, conversion
failures are properly reported. Documentation is updated accordingly.
- Pretty signature of invalid values is set to "Invalid".

Change-Id: Ic630fb714865a2895f495d8f6847dcc61213e19b

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
TransportSocketCache: Fixed a race on socket disconnection (fixes #38167)

The context:
You ask a socket for an url from the cache. You disconnect the socket, and immediately
ask a socket for the same url from the cache. Depending on the race, you can
end up with a disconnected socket, instead of a connected one.
The race is between the disconnection of the socket and the receiving of the
`disconnected` signal by the cache. If this signal arrives too late, the socket
is still in the cache when we ask it, and it is returned although it is
disconnected.

Change-Id: Ife655f7b2c8d8b6c5eddc08b801d1f41ac8f1b52

data.author: JoÃ«l LAMOTTE
data.message:
DynamicObject/Property: fixes contradictory property advertisement implementation.

When using the `DynamicObjectBuilder::advertiseProperty` function
we first advertise a signal with the name of the property,
then advertise the property.
However, advertising the property will result in a call
to `MetaObjectPrivate::addProperty` which throws
if a member already has the name provided as parameter.
To avoid this issue, since we already know
the id to provide, we should just ignore the check in this case
and let the user be responsible for the combination.
If the id is not provided, we do the check as before.

Fixed tests_messaging_session_pair in all modes
at least on Windows.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Rewrite message socket in a modular and generic way.

(some unit tests do not currently pass, but reviews can already be done, the
main part of the code being not likely to change)

The previous socket code was tangled, resulting in a lot of hard-to-track bugs.
Now, the code is cleanly structured with components, each one being as generic
as possible, and having a single responsibility.

Each socket state (disconnected, connecting, connected, disconnecting) is handled
by a separate type, and gathers available operations and associated data.
Also, free "regular" functions are used as much as possible.
This way, data sharing is minimized, making impossible a lot of concurrency
problems.

Each state delegates underlying socket operations to types and functions that
effectively connect, send, receive messages, etc.

Each of these components (types and functions) does as little assumptions about
its environment as possible, by letting the user decide:
- how the socket is locked (not at all, with a mutex, etc.)
- how the lifetime of data is managed (not at all, protected with a Trackable, etc.)
- how the network operations are protected (not at all, with a strand, etc.)

Each component can of course be used by itself, independently of the
message socket.

The code being generic, all concepts have been formally defined.
The message socket itself is parametrized by a `Network` type, that gives access
to types and functions handling the underlying network operations.
In production code, this `Network` type fallbacks to Boost.Asio.
In unit tests, a mock is used to control all network operations, and cause
errors on-demand.

Change-Id: Id4f31e205961c62a28913396d0519f94e2b172e9

data.author: Victor PALEOLOGUE
data.message:
Signal: fix disconnection deadlocks and get rid of "waitForInactive"

Considering the fact that onSubscribers can be given by anyone to a Signal,
it is extremely dangerous to call it synchronously from a critical section!
This caused deadlocks in separate projects, that could not be reproduced
in the attached tests. The attached tests were however still improving the
coverage and worth keeping.

As a consequence, the fix revealed the inconsistency of the
"waitForInactive" feature, that causes more problems it tries to solve:
it tries to bring a guarantee that callbacks are not running anymore
after the signal is disconnected, but it should be the user's
responsibility to manage the lifetime of his or her callbacks and use
mutexing, stranding and tracking to prevent doing bad things.

By trying to do too much, we ended up waiting in very complex
configurations, causing deadlocks that the user could not even predict.

Change-Id: I3b4a01f5c8441f6f3963769b8b2f2c944142ffc6
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/80711
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: vpaleologue <vpaleologue@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
Fix: when a RemoteObject receive a call, forward to related ObjectHosts.

When we detect that a RemoteObject received a call, it's a message
routing error. However because of object id collisions (their values
are defined by a counter in each process, so it's possible for
two objects from two different processes to end up
sending messages with the same objectid) we should also check if the
real destination object isn't an host of the RemoteObject before
dropping the message (resulting in an infinite wait for the caller).

This does not fix the object identification issue, it can only
be fixed by changing the design of the messaging protocol.

Change-Id: I599f761af7acda235365b071806caad1281e065c
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/78490
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

data.author: jlanca
data.message:
Fix heap-use-after-free in serializeObject

serializeObject dereferenced a pointer with no guarantee that the pointed
data is still valid when the function is executed.

ServiceBoundObject::_gethost() should return a weak_ptr to let the
callbacks lock it and check if the host is still alive.

TSAN report that revealed the issue:
http://pastebin.aldebaran.lan/view/4cc5ff91
backtraces of a segfault that exposes the issue:
http://pastebin.aldebaran.lan/view/adc7f116

Note: serializeObject also takes a StreamContext* argument, there is no
guarantee that it is valid either during the callback execution.
I don't think we attempt to dereference it anywhere though, so I did not
change that.

Additionally:

 - added comments clarifying untrivial parts of the related code;
 - revealed and fixed invalid iterator accesses in Gateway impl;
 - removed unused signal;

Change-Id: I385c8b8ef27bdb30a05f101a10916bf234fe9065

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
Fixed issues with QI_THREAD_SAFE_NEW tests.

 - removed unused code;
 - added deletion of static new-ed objects, to avoid false-positive
   leak reports;
 - added clarification of why this test cannot be launched in repeat
   mode;
 - fixed thread usage being random: our boost.thread version v2 will
   detach the thread on destruction, which made the rest of the
   test have undefined behaviour.
   Now (using std::thread) we guarantee that all the threads are joined
   before looking at the shared counters.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Added a Scoped type to execute, in a RAII style, an arbitrary routine on scope exit.

Can be used to free a resource from a C api (e.g. fopen / fclose), restore
an initial value (e.g. change flags for formatted output and restore them),
or simply execute some code on code exit (log...), etc.
An release mechanism can be easily implemented on top, by avoiding the
function to be called under certain conditions.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Made the Regular concept checking complete.

As the Regular concept is the foundation of generic programming with value
semantics, it is necessary to be able to automatically check if a type
respect these constraints.
It is now checked if == is an equivalence, and < a total ordering.
Predicates have been added to check these properties on a relation.
isRegular now take as input a range of values, which ideally contains all
the values in the type to be tested for regularity.
added.

data.author: jlanca
data.message:
Fix deadlock when disconnecting a signal from the callback

The deadlock would happen when disconnecting from the callback, if the
SignalSubscriber already had one active thread. The thread disconnecting
from the callback would wait for the inactive promise to be set.
This should normally happen when the first active thread terminates.

However, when it terminated, we checked if it was the last active thread
(and set the promise in this case only). That was incorrect, since there
was another activeThread (the one waiting for inactive).
The correct thing to check when removing an active thread is:
if all remaining threads are waiting for inactive, set inactive.

Change-Id: I8893e5ca8ae699028ce7d6b4cbe828a30305d687
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/77220
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Joël LAMOTTE
data.message:
Fixed: dead data access through SignalSubscriber::linkId.

As a reference, the location linkId refered to was decided once and for all at construction.
This meant that, as soon as the SignalSubscriber was assigned to,
linkId was not referring to the right location anymore, but to the old one.
This resulted in modifying other objets or dead memory.
According to SignalSubscriber use in libqi, this rarely caused a problem
because we tended to copy these objects without destroying the original.

However, this is a public interface, which implies that users can
end up with random crashes by accessing linkId. So until
we change version we cannot remove linkId, but will do so soon,
as the deprecation warning already suggests.

Change-Id: I3282195a33e2c3c193c8d4b6e37d00b05f7805e6

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Added macros to generate Regular relational operators (==, <, and others).

Equality is central to generic value-semantic programming, so we need an
easy way to generate it. It would be nice if the compiler could generate
operator== with memberwise equality, but it is not currently possible.
Same thing for operator<.
Added also the possibility to automatically generate !=, <= and >= in terms
of == and <.
All generated operators behave correctly with each other :
== is an equivalence and < is a total ordering.
Macros are used because in the current state of the language (C++11) it is
the least bad solution.

Change-Id: I520000d1ab0ffe5577ada43bbb47194c88956d6e
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/73106

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Added isRegular() to help developpers check their types really follows value semantics.

More precisely, it checks that the copy and assignment are coherent with equality.
Archeological note : this quite old code was historically written for the
equality of objects (ptruid), which was later (temporarily) reverted.
As this code is in fact independent of object equality and needed for further
works, it is now in its own commit.

Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Added a erase_if algorithm.

It is needed for a incoming bug fix.
It is a implementation of the C++17 version specified in
http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg21/docs/papers/2016/n4600.html#container.erasure.erase_if
It is optimized for contiguous sequences and list sequences.
Type traits were added to do the static dispatch.

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Test enhancements: stop loops in lambdas when assertion fails.

In the case of inner functions failing assertion tests in an outer loop
the assertion is logged and return the inner function,
so the outer function is never stopped even if it's an ASSERT_*
We now use a variant of the assertion macros which, collaborating
with the function caller, will throw the assertion information and
the exception will be catch to be logged, the message containing the
problem line source info.

Also made sure that the worker thread used in the tests is joined
correctly even in case of exception failure.

data.author: vpaleologue
data.message:
Signal: allow async connection / disconnection to prevent deadlocks

Using the synchronous version is actually dangerous! But since it is
already used in various ways that would not accept to switch the return
type to a FutureSync, there was no better way than providing an explicit
way to do this asynchronously.

To enable asynchronicity, we could not return references anymore (Futures
would not support it for good reasons), so we need to switch fully to
entity semantics for SignalSubscriber instances. Therefore we can get rid
of enabling shared_from_this.

Change-Id: I31b2b350b68d807ef0e9cd49b90b1a11768497d0

data.message:
deprecate qi::PromiseNoop #34827

and

* remove its internal uses
* fix a few cancel-related docstrings

isCancelable is meaningless (always return true) and deprecated since 2.5.

Hence, qi::PromiseNoop, which was used as a no-op cancel callback
to make a Promise cancelable is not useful anymore (every Promise is
considered cancelable irrespective of having a callback or not).

data.author: hcuche
data.message:
Do not throw in FutureSync destructor anymore

* FutureSync must synchronize on destruction to ensure that the task is finished.
Until now, it did a future.value() which caused an exception to be thrown in case of error.
Now, a future.wait() is performed, meaning any error will be "swallowed".
This prevents that 2 exceptions run at once (and the abort that follows).
If the user wants to check for error, he can call explicitly wait() before destruction,
or assign to the underlying type.

Change-Id: Icb5ef7d530b65da8e0649500501cd661590f3819
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/75114
