data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Fixed a gateway deadlock related to object properties

As often, the deadlock was caused by the gateway redirecting the message
to the caller, a RemoteObject, that discarded it by not being able to treat it.
This fix is in fact a workaround that so far seems ok but could be dangerous :
it tries to prevent the gateway to redirect the message to its caller by
detecting that the source socket and the destination one are the same.
In this case, it searches a map of sockets populated when the harvesting fails
because the metaobject was not found, and uses the first socket found, if any.

Change-Id: Idc2cd4af8470f15e92f80ca4dfe534af513d6d1a

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Equality now works even if objects travel through the network.

Until now, equality of Objects was equality of their pointers, so if an object
was sent to a service and returned, it would not be equal to the original
object anymore.
An object id is in fact a hash on the pointer passed to the object at the time
of its creation. This hash is a sha1 hash on the concatenation of the machine
uuid, the process uuid and the pointer value. An uuid is used for the process
instead of the process id to avoid different pointers at different times having
the same hash due to process id recycling.
A debug mode also exists where the first number of PtrUid is deterministic
(i.e. it doesn't change at each executions).

Change-Id: Ica9d9083ed64b9935acc814115f9be61a7929023
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/72787
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>

Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Romain Vimont
data.message:
Set socket options for SSL

The socket options, including tcp keepalive, were set only for non-SSL
connections.

As a consequence, switching the endpoint protocol from tcp to tcps
impacted the detection of socket disconnection due to timeout.
Concretely, in tcps, the session signal "disconnected" were not received
in all cases.

Therefore, set the same socket options for SSL connections.

Change-Id: I5c53d3a98e49eca6972bc77fea0c2436bfc28a56
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/73139
Reviewed-by: rvimont <rvimont@presta.aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: epinault <epinault@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Joël Lamotte
data.message:
HotFix5 Gatway

Hotfix4 replaced a deadlock in the gateway on failed
authentification attempt by a race which makes
the gateway unstable and difficult to predict.

This is the same fix but without the race,
which should make the gateway stable for failed
attempts to connect.

Change-Id: Ic5c0b0413aae2484479929b323ca1498eb34f8ef
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/72724
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: hcuche <hcuche@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Romain Vimont
data.message:
Release the mutex before executing callbacks

The future mutex was kept while executing callbacks, which may take an
arbitrary amount of time to complete.

As a consequence, a simple call to cancel() could wait for the mutex
until all the callbacks execution is complete.

Instead, release the mutex before calling the callbacks.

Related to <https://partner-portal.aldebaran.com/issues/2262>.

Change-Id: I3214b4cd01f03a43ac59e064bcdac3548aee24c5
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/72629
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: rvimont <rvimont@presta.aldebaran.com>

data.author: Romain Vimont
data.message:
Set socket options for SSL

The socket options, including tcp keepalive, were set only for non-SSL
connections.

As a consequence, switching the endpoint protocol from tcp to tcps
impacted the detection of socket disconnection due to timeout.
Concretely, in tcps, the session signal "disconnected" were not received
in all cases.

Therefore, set the same socket options for SSL connections.

Change-Id: I5c53d3a98e49eca6972bc77fea0c2436bfc28a56
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/73139

data.author: Joël Lamotte
data.message:
HotFix5 Gatway

Hotfix4 replaced a deadlock in the gateway on failed
authentification attempt by a race which makes
the gateway unstable and difficult to predict.

This is the same fix but without the race,
which should make the gateway stable for failed
attempts to connect.

Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/72724

Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Romain Vimont
data.message:
Release the mutex before executing callbacks

The future mutex was kept while executing callbacks, which may take an
arbitrary amount of time to complete.

As a consequence, a simple call to cancel() could wait for the mutex
until all the callbacks execution is complete.

Instead, release the mutex before calling the callbacks.

Related to <https://partner-portal.aldebaran.com/issues/2262>.

Change-Id: I3214b4cd01f03a43ac59e064bcdac3548aee24c5
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/72629
Reviewed-by: jmonnon <jmonnon@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: rvimont <rvimont@presta.aldebaran.com>

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Gateway Hotfix4 : additional searches of source of objects.

When we have a complex sequence of calls of remote objects, the
gateway can lose track of which object is where. When such object is
called from multiple chain of remote objects, the gateway might not
find the destination object.
In this hotfix we look for all the possibilities before
stopping searching for objects information referenced in the gateway,
or for sockets from which the objects originate from.

Change-Id: Ib497ee3c2a01289902d1eb03037a33cb7710f989
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/72314
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Fixed buffer content logging calling isgraph() with invalid values.

The issue triggered assertion failures in debug mode on visual studio.

The requirements of isgraph(c) is that c must be a int containing
a value which could be represented in an unsigned char.
Therefore, providing a negative char or int value is
undefined behaviour.

data.author: vpaleologue
data.message:
Hotfix Gateway 3.

Gateway filters objects from messages but ignoreed when there is
a set message to a property which contain an object that could
be called later. Therefore, an Object in a property will not be
seen by the Gateway and when a call to it's members is done, the
Gateway will never find the actual object and will just send it
back to the sender (after forwarding the message all around the
world).

We now force scan messages for objects even when it's not
necessarily objects, just removed the test which predict if the
message have objects or not, it is incomplete anyway.

Change-Id: Ibf5da463b750cbd6be4d0c44460b94f849de367e
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/72248

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Gateway Hotfix4 : additional searches of source of objects.

When we have a complex sequence of calls of remote objects, the
gateway can lose track of which object is where. When such object is
called from multiple chain of remote objects, the gateway might not
find the destination object.
In this hotfix we look for all the possibilities before
stopping searching for objects information referenced in the gateway,
or for sockets from which the objects originate from.

Change-Id: Ib497ee3c2a01289902d1eb03037a33cb7710f989

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Fixed buffer content logging calling isgraph() with invalid values.

The issue triggered assertion failures in debug mode on visual studio.

The requirements of isgraph(c) is that c must be a int containing
a value which could be represented in an unsigned char.
Therefore, providing a negative char or int value is
undefined behaviour.

data.author: vpaleologue
data.message:
Hotfix Gateway 3.

Gateway filters objects from messages but ignoreed when there is
a set message to a property which contain an object that could
be called later. Therefore, an Object in a property will not be
seen by the Gateway and when a call to it's members is done, the
Gateway will never find the actual object and will just send it
back to the sender (after forwarding the message all around the
world).

We now force scan messages for objects even when it's not
necessarily objects, just removed the test which predict if the
message have objects or not, it is incomplete anyway.

data.author: Jeremy Monnon
data.message:
Equality now works even if objects travel through the network.

Until now, equality of Objects was equality of their pointers, so if an object
was sent to a service and returned, it would not be equal to the original
object anymore.
An object id is in fact a hash on the pointer passed to the object at the time
of its creation. This hash is a sha1 hash on the concatenation of the machine
uuid, the process uuid and the pointer value. An uuid is used for the process
instead of the process id to avoid different pointers at different times having
the same hash due to process id recycling.

Change-Id: I5dfa3b03bd60812b65330fb143588fdefaf71a40
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/71895
Reviewed-by: vpaleologue <vpaleologue@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: vpaleologue <vpaleologue@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Fix: don't continue processing method calls on unavailable objects.

This is a quickfix for a design issue.
Basically, on session destruction/disconnect, the gatway
might lose access to objects which have been called by a signal.
The original gateway code assumed that if we got a call,
then we necessarily still have a way to find the object.
This was checked by an assertion but it actually happens
and this case should abort the call attempt.

I don't think that throwing an exception is the best way to
abort the call, but I believe that a refactoring is necessary to
improve the gateway code and allow checking this case efficiently.

I tried to just return a boolean telling if or not we executed the
call, but it seems to impact all the calling code and trigger other
cases which also seem to assume that the object must be registerd,
which is incorrect.

Change-Id: I540233667cbc290507dc1772735195d7ed46afa1
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/68225
Reviewed-by: hcuche <hcuche@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: hcuche
data.message:
Add QI_ASSERT() macros.

These macros will help to customize the assertion usage in the future.
Currently, it allows to have a better behaviour with MSVC.
C's assert is only guaranteed to fail so the implementation can do
anything it wants. With GCC and clang you get nice error context so
it's ok.
With other compilers (including MSVC) there is less useful information,
for example abort can be called without any debugging information.
This is all because assert macro implementation is not defined by
the standard.

To help with that, we need to control the implementation of the
assertion macros so that we can tweak it to match our use.
This is also the beginning of allowing several useful tweaks to help
with debugging:

 - allow assertions in non-debug modes (c's assert cannot do that);
 - customize assertion behaviour (for example to log, breakpoint, then
   continue if assertions are activated in release mode,
   which can be useful to hunt
   nasty bugs that cannot happen in debug but can happen in release);

and other assertion behavior variants. It is also possible
to make it customizable on a per-process basis, which can help debugging
critical processes.

Note: This is not an alternative to throwing exceptions or error codes,
it's exclusively an internal debugging tools which help us before
releasing binaries.

This change helps with debugging the gateway.

Change-Id: I34ddafa9932fd53321efdce141c7da14a6f1cec2
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/68092
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: jmartin <jmartin@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Reviewed-by: hcuche <hcuche@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.message:
make qi::Path conversion to string operator explicit

because

1/ conversion from qi::Path to string is mostly needed when communicating
with external libraries, which are unlikely adhere to its "always utf-8"
policy. So better avoid the silent conversion.

2/ this conversion causes ambiguities in overload resolution. For
instance this did not compile:

  qi::Path qip;
  boost::filesystem::path bfsp(qip);

data.author: hcuche
data.message:
Added UnsafeProperty

UnsafeProperty is exactly the same thing that Property without
the thread-safety. It should be used in very specific cases
where we know that no concurrent access can occur.
It also does not provide scoped access to the value as there is no
thread-safety.

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Added thread-safe access to Property's value.

 - Fixes #25787
 - Fixes #25788
 - Added basic Property tests.
 - Added missing Property's scoped lock accessors with associated tests.
 - Property accessors are returning FutureSync for safety.
 - Moved thread-safety from PropertyImpl to Property.
 - PropertyImpl child types are not thread safe by default,
   which helps implementing additional thread-sadety strategy in these types.
 - Added documentation.

data.message:

reached our destructor, it means that the ObjectHost does not own us anymore, no
need to remove ourself from it.

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Fixed: proxy object being constructed on each call.

Potential fix for #32769

This leads to memory leaks and call stack explosion (calling the proxy
spawn a new object and then call each instantiated object recursively).

 - Proxy registration now imply declaring the interface type as
   parent type of the implementation/proxy type;
 - changed the inheritance failure value to never match an actual
   possible value;

data.author: Philippe Daouadi
data.message:
Future.thenR: do not forward cancel even with actors

When we do a future.thenR(callback), the callback *must* be called even when the
future returned by .thenR is canceled.

Before this patch, when we canceled the future returned by .thenR(somecallback,
someactor), the future returned was linked to the one returned by
Strand.async(), which is cancelable.

Change-Id: Id590d13e61c222a045656b5c71047787ddef92cb
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/64301
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: pdaouadi <pdaouadi@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Fixed: use _WIN32, not WIN32

_WIN32 is provided by the compiler and is reserved, while WIN32 is
provided by the environment and could be overwrite by the user code.

data.message:
Feature #31605: PAM Unix login authentication

Add authenticators interacting with the PAM Unix login feature.

the user on the robot.

and `pam_pass` in the network capabilities.

data.author: Philippe Daouadi
data.message:
ObjectHost: use different ids between BoundObject and RemoteObject

When passing an object through a RemoteObject pointing to a service (let's say
2), this object gets this service's id and a generated object id, on the client
side (let's say 2.3). This id may collide with an object generated on the
service side.

This causes issues for example when the service makes a call to the object and
it needs to route the response to the correct object (since two objects have the
same id on the service side).

Change-Id: I7248c3b0cd7f944429f4a384794ffaba0f03d77a
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/60867
Reviewed-by: pdaouadi <pdaouadi@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: tfontenay
data.message:
Fix deadlock on specific setProperty situation

The situation was as follow:
- you own an object
- you give it to a remote service
- you acquire an AnyObject from said service which actually points
to your original object

Trying to setProperty on that AnyObject would deadlock (two nested
synchronous calls on the same socket which prevents it from
calling continueReading()).

Change-Id: I6334f5d485013884b23355db01809fbfda1ea277

data.author: jlamotte
data.message:
Removed the requirement of having to call Trackable constructor with "this".

When T inherit from Trackable<T> we are previously forced to pass
T's this pointer to the Trackable constructor in T's constructor.
Now this is optional: the default constructor of Trackable<T> will just
assume that it is static_cast-able to T and obtain T's this pointer this way.
This should help the user to avoid boilerplate.

Change-Id: I3b12882e500a75ef79a2f9109da97ec9b72167dc

data.author: Sébastien Barthélémy
data.message:
qi::log: timestamp with both qi::SystemClock and qi::Clock (#30435)

There is now two kinds of log handlers:

* qi::log::logFuncHandler, deprecated, which only takes the qi::SystemClock
  date as a qi::os::timeval.

* qi::log::Handler, which takes both the qi::Clock and qi::SystemClock
  dates as time_points.

So this change does not break the older log handlers.

--qi-log-context supports both dates:

* --qi-log-context=4 will keep printing the qi::SystemClock dates.

* --qi-log-context=256 will print the qi::Clock dates.

* --qi-log-context=260 will print both kinds of dates.

Note that while backward compatibility was kept for the numeric context, the
enum LogContextAttr was changed::

  -LogContextAttr_Date           = 1 << 2, ///< Show qi::SystemClock dates
  +LogContextAttr_SystemDate     = 1 << 2, ///< Show qi::SystemClock dates
  +LogContextAttr_Date           = 1 << 8, ///< Show qi::Clock dates

So, code which used LogContextAttr_Date should now use LogContextAttr_SystemDate.

Change-Id: I8564d72b199c607cab75a48250610127c3bb79ba
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/57881
Reviewed-by: hcuche <hcuche@aldebaran.com>
Reviewed-by: sbarthelemy <sbarthelemy@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Sébastien Barthélémy
data.message:
tweak qi::SteadyClock and qi::os::ustime (#1973)

change the epoch of qi::SteadyClock to the program start time, in order
to avoid confusion with qi::Clock and to ensure it is *not* system-wise:
boost::chrono::steady_clock is system-wide, but C++ makes no such
requirement for std::chrono::steady_clock.

Also use qi::SteadyClock for qi::os::ustime, which thus becomes
monotonic.

Change-Id: I773e77895507f13a30f7a0e5c9f17f00084b782e
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/57072
Reviewed-by: sbarthelemy <sbarthelemy@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: sbarthelemy <sbarthelemy@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Sébastien Barthélémy
data.message:
add qi::Clock (#1973)

add qi::Clock which comes in addition to qi::SteadyClock and qi::SystemClock
and should be used for system-wide timestamps.

The clock will eventually be monotonic, based on boost::chrono::steady_clock,
but is currently based on boost::chrono::system_clock to keep
compatiblity while all timestamps are migrated from
gettimeofday to qi::Clock.

Move the to/fromUint32 helpers from SteadyClock to Clock. (This is an
API breakage, hopefully these helpers are not used).

Change-Id: I8a1733c089c3ee3ea2015dedee45ad17a88740b0
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/57174
Reviewed-by: sbarthelemy <sbarthelemy@aldebaran.com>
Tested-by: sbarthelemy <sbarthelemy@aldebaran.com>

data.author: Sébastien Barthélémy
data.message:
add constructors to qi::os::timeval (#1973)

This commit adds

* a constructor taking a qi::Duration, which normalizes the tv
* a constructor taking int64_t usec, which normalizes the tv
* a constructor taking sec and usec, which does *not* normalize the tv
* a default contructor to qi::os::timeval, which initializes it to 0.

Note that, following this change, this user code will not compile
anymore:

  qi::os::timeval tv = {1, 2};

it should be replaced with:

  qi::os::timeval tv(1,2);

A timeval is said to be normalized if the number of microseconds is
in [0, 1000000[.

A conversion constructor is now used in qi::os::gettimeofday, which
means the resulting timeval will be normalized.
This slightly changes the behavior of gettimeofday() for negative dates.

Change-Id: I38b3618e626bd02f75b7dba3100b871c68e978e3
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/56940
Reviewed-by: jlamotte <jlamotte@aldebaran.com>

data.author: tfontenay
data.message:
Fix a potential deadlock in RemoteObject

When the remoteobject is closed, it unregisters itself from the socket's
messages and set all its promises to Error. However if the RO is closed
during a metacall, it can happen that the metacall pushes its promise
_after_ the cleanup, leaving it hanging. Since the RO is not receiving
any more message from the socket the promise can never be set.
This patch verifies that a close has not run during a metacall.

Change-Id: I6d7a0560ebcad7a1885a7fd435fa24976e04dc02
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/55927
Tested-by: gerrit
Reviewed-by: pdaouadi <pdaouadi@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Approved: tfontenay <tfontenay@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Reviewed-by: tfontenay <tfontenay@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: tfontenay <tfontenay@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: tfontenay
data.message:
Close network objects when last remote references die suddenly

Keep track of remote references for network objects, and remove those
references when the holder dies unexpectedly.
Clients that die unexpectedly do not send a `terminate` message to the objects
they own, making them dangling server-side.

data.author: tfontenay
data.message:
Fix a bug/deadlock when capabilities are sent twice (retrocompat)

this could trigger an issue with an ill-formed condition in
tcptransportsocket leading to a potential deadlock.

data.message:
rm duplicate test test_qipath_from_bin

this test was identical to test_qipath, but meant to be
run from another directory (thanks to qi_create_gtest's
WORKING_DIRECTORY option).

However

* running both test_qipath and test_qipath_from_bin
  concurrently does not work, which breaks qitest run -j8.

So let just remove the test.

data.author: Philippe Daouadi
data.message:
Remove TemplateTypeInterface

A template is not a type and that was very badly handled. Now template types
are registered as objects and are handled as such (useful when returning such
types over the network or to other languages). We never had problems with that
because the only cases were Future<T> and friends.

data.author: tfontenay

different orders in different thread. Move the BO's mutex acquisition
earlier so that the order is the same in both threads.

data.author: tfontenay
data.message:
Close RemoteObjects when unregistered

In some specific cases, this prevents deadlocks when RemoteObjects
are not closed properly (if the ROs are unregistered and the session
closes before the sockets die, the ROs are not closed and potential
futures will keep on waiting for answers that might not come).

Change-Id: Ic3726d2a30beed3d46a8ade50298a3f9cd91a127

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
registerProxy: Fix support for legacy mode.

The mode without interface, frontend QI_REGISTER_PROXY() was

data.author: Philippe Daouadi
data.message:
Signal: Release lock before waiting for callbacks on disconnect

Scenario:
- A is being called by signal S
- B calls disconnectAll on S, B is waiting for A to finish
- A (in the callback) tries to disconnect itself but the mutex is already taken
- Deadlock

data.message:
EventLoop: tunning of thread creation heuristic.

Add the following environment variables and default values:

- QI_EVENTLOOP_MAX_THREADS: Upper thread limit (200)
- QI_EVENTLOOP_PING_TIMEOUT: Ping timeout that causes a thread creation (500ms)
- QI_EVENTLOOP_GRACE_PERIOD: Grace period after thread creation to restart a ping (0ms)

data.author: Sébastien Barthélémy
data.message:
add clock API based on boost::{chrono,thread}

We mimic the clocks and sleep functions from chrono and thread (in boost
and c++11) and use boost (both chrono and thread) for the
implementation.

* why do we need clocks in libqi?

We could tell people to just use boost::chrono.
But in the future, we want to enable sharing the clock epoch accross
processors and pausing the time (for simulations).
We also probably need common types for durations and time_points accross
all platforms.

* why do we need sleep in libqi?

  We could tell people to just use boost::thread, but that would not work
  for boost::thread <1.50 which has no boost::chrono support, and again,
  once pausing time is implemented, we'll need a specialized sleep_for.

* ok, but right now, why not a simple typedef for clocks?

  indeed, while pausing time is not implemented, a mere

  namespace qi {
  typedef boost::chrono::system_clock system_clock;
  typedef boost::chrono::steady_clock steady_clock;
  }

  would basically do it. However, 1) the steady_clock class also provides a
  fine place where to put the from_int32... utils 2) it enables us to use
  int64_t instead of intleast64_t as rep.

Part of redmine #17438

Change-Id: I28139b1791ce51fdfefe6585f9ddef6f0d178825

data.author: Herve CUCHE
data.message:
LOG: Fix bad glob checking on setCategory

Updating an existing filter with setCategory updates the value
without changing the position of the filter in the ordered list,
but it also updated existing categories as if the filter was the last element of the list.
Change that last bit by reprocessing the whole filter list
for each category that matches the updated filter.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Socket: Fix a destruction race by binding the SocketPtr in async calls.

Likely triggered by choregraphe win32.

We reset the socket shared ptr on disconnection, so its
lifespam is shorter than the TransportSocket object, so
passing a shared_from_this() to the asio callback does
not keep the Socket live.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Session: Fix a race where serviceRegistered is called too soon.

serviceRegistered is called before final registration into internal
map. So a callback immediately calling service() can end up in
a code path believing the service is remote.
This will 'work' but use a tcp connection to self, which is to suboptimal
what opening a beer bottle with a railgun is to overkill.

Change-Id: I3a6585836d07e1bd165378e6bcefcd2e68186036
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/29482

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
python: Use a leak stack to track and clean allocated stuff.

Code in type conversion allocates result, where it should peek
from existing values. Not allocating is hard, and per-value
tracking can't be acomplished. So use a stack of allocated
AnyReference, that is cleaned by caller of operations that are
known to allocate.

Change-Id: I13fc4e4cbe92e8e46236a61b6bbb6201512e9a21

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Proxy: Switch to fully hidden proxysignal/property.

Previously, ProxySignal and ProxyProperty had members, thus preventing
an object Interface for having simple Signal and Property members.

Now required data is bound in callback functions, and a Signal or Property
can be converted to a proxy.

Change-Id: Ief3cfe3a8f8504d43a91d2e3fa808655fe3ed6c5

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
GenericObject: Bring refcounter down by using enable_shared_from_this.

The point is to hold the AnyObject while a call is being made.

Consider:

   {
   AnyObject ao(new Something);
   ao->post("method");
   }

This used to segv, since post had no way to hold a ref count, having no knowledge of
'ao'. Now it uses shared_from_this() to pass an AnyObject as call context (which
used to be Manageable*).

One bad consequence is that a GenericObject cannot be used without constructing
a shared_ptr on it. If not done, first call will fail by throwing a boost::bad_weak_ptr.

Change-Id: Ib2783bcbdb96729c994f8786095e49b6d2a94f20
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan/23776
Tested-by: gerrit
Reviewed-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
ALProxy generation.

Will likely only work from runtime data and not IDL because of expectations
on method documentation format (which the IDL spec does not handle yet).

Tries to be as close as possible from previous generator behavior, so
please do not play with indent/spacing of generated code for other
reasons.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
TcpTransportSocket: delete the socket ASAP.

Reverts 2057f8 Matthieu Nottale > Keep io_service alive while socket exists.

Take a different approach: kill the socket as soon as possible.

Since we have no explicit tracking of async ops, Pass around the socket
in a shared_ptr.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Signal: use 64bit Link.

A hack that makes us all safer.
TypeSystem uses a Link typedef that needs to be 64bits.
So if you use Signal::Link instead of Type::Link, you end up truncating
the signal id, which fubars everything.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
GV/GVP: Remove error-prone API elements.

Remove all GVP factory/ctors that allocate. Feed a GVP to a GV
if you want that, or clone it.
Otherwise the risk of a leak by doing GenericValue foo(gvpFactory()); is
too big.
Remove GVP::ref, use GVR constructor instead.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
SocketCache: Improve endpoint filtering.

I would like to not filter out non-local endpoints if remote has same
machineid, but it breaks. It should not. Multiple connections attempt code
is just not working.

- Detect localhost as a local endpoint.
- Set error if there is no endpoint after filtering, instead of silently
blocking forever.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
serialization: ObjectPtr support.

We use new class ObjectHost (ServiceBoundObject or RemoteObject basically)
as a serialization context, and directly a TransportSocketPtr as
a deserialization context.

The serialization process produces a SBO that registers to the
ObjectHost.
The deserialization process produces a RemoteObject that hooks
the TransportSocket.

Change-Id: I720c22e84170dd0aff3bb9f7b1f16b6291633de3

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Signature: Allow signature mismatch for Unknown kind.

Why?
- ObjectPtr has signature object and is (will be)serializable.
- Foo where an ObjectTypeBuilder is present is not serializable, we want
to limit serialization to ObjectPtr and other shared_ptr, ie things we
can track.
- But, ObjectPtr can be converted to Foo and Foo* and we want to keep it that way.

But currently the call fails early because of the signature mismatch.

So work around that by considering X a compatible type, since we won't reach
serialization code anyway, and the Type system will ensure type compatiblity
within call().

Change-Id: I20e36024d9a958ccb0f35da7c694f93ed0603bb5

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
signal/metaCall: Switch from explicit EventLoop control to thread model.

Manual event loop control was tedious.

Now we control:
  -thread-safeness at object level
  -sync/async at bindMethod/connectEvent and call/emit level.

We use a timed_mutex to detect possible deadlocks.
It is itself wrapped in a shared_ptr because in some
cases we do not lock the ObjectPtr when performing a call
(ex: non-member function bound on a DynamicObject).

Change-Id: Iffa7f30b92c5b7ae6190bb9df69cc5aa04bf1af7
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/10337
Reviewed-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Store Manageable exclusively in GenericObject.

We need a context to store per-instance informations: Manageable.

Previous code was broken: GenericObject inherits from Manageable, but
this Manageable* was not available from StaticObjectType methods.

Now Manageable is provided by GenericObject only, and is passed on in
ObjectType interface methods.

data.author: Franck Michea
data.message:
qipython: Raise known python exceptions from C++.

This commit permits to raise exceptions from C++ with their valid classes
defined in python. Until that patch, exceptions launched with qi_raise were not
catchable by their exact name, but only with Exception, even if their name
matched an actual exception with the same name (weird).

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
API: New QI_LIB_API(libname) macro to handle import/export.

From the doc:

/** @return the proper type specification for import/export
 * @param libname the name of your library.
 * This macro will use two preprocessor defines:
 * libname_EXPORTS (cmake convention) and libname_STATIC_BUILD.
 * Those macro can be unset or set to 0 to mean false, or set to empty or 1 to
 * mean true.
 * The first one must be true if the current compilation unit is within the library.
 * The second must be true if the library was built as a static archive.
 * The proper way to use this macro is to:
 * - Have your buildsystem set mylib_EXPORTS when building MYLIB
 * - Have your buildsystem produce a config.h file that
     #define mylib_STATIC_BUILD to 1 or empty if it is a static build, and
     not define mylib_STATIC_BUILD or define it to 0 otherwise
 * In one header, write
 *   #include <mylib/config.h>
 *   #define MYLIB_API QI_LIB_API(mylib)
*/

Change-Id: Ifef29a69a4041774d987c661760e0e6a073e129f
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/7258
Reviewed-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
makeGenericFunction: Workaround a weird vcxx bug.

    When makeGenericFunction or a wrapper was invoked with
    a forced FUNCTION_TYPE of the form 'int(int)', which
    is a function signature type, but *not* the type
    of any function or function pointer value,
    generated code would segv on call under vcxx.

    Taking FT by value instead of by const reference seems to
    fix the problem.

Change-Id: I633fdbc8ac2089a4e203f3e98a1ae8f60f22bf32
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/6792
Reviewed-by: cgestes <gestes@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Fix template dllexport/import on all platforms.

Pay attention, it makes perfect sense but you need to focus:

- under gcc-macos if the template is not declared QITYPE_API, then
typeid do not match between instances created in different
libraries. This breaks Signal on Future<GenericValue> argument.
- under vcxx-win32 if the template is declared QITYPE_API, then
all instanciations that will ever be used need to be present
in the source library.
- under linux: good voodoo, it works anyway.

So the solution is to not declare the template QITYPE_API, but
to declare specific instances as QITYPE_API.

Change-Id: I077c208da01e666a2763b623dcedf1758d2f84aa
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/6838
Reviewed-by: cgestes <gestes@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: cgestes <gestes@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Remove virtual inheritance, and thus the need to dynamic_cast at many places.

We provide a Type implementation, TypeImplMethods that does *not* inherit
from Type, and a macro _QI_BOUNCE_TYPE_METHODS that create virtual
bouncers to it in specific impls.

convert2 is now 10 times faster in some cases, and faster than convert
in most cases.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
MetaType: Workaround visual C++ glitch.

Visual does not extract the const properly: in

  template<typename T> void foo(const T& v);
  foo("coin");

T can be "const char[5]"

so add remote_const where appropriate.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Shortcut serialization for local calls with same sig.

Make all functors we register go through BoostFunctor. Then in call(),
if metamethod::functor is present (local call), try to dynamic_cast it
using the signature of the call arguments. If it matches (safe check),
make the call by directly invoking the boost::function. Otherwise, go
through serialization.

->10% performance gain on perf_transport.

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Buffer: On-demand allocation of BufferPrivate.

For peformance reasons, see for example the usual pattern
  Message m; // Allocates a BufferPrivate as m._p->buffer->_p
  Buffer b;
  <fill b>
  m.setBufer(b); // Deallocates unused m.buffer

But this is tricky: You do not want to break the sharing effect of
  Buffer a; Buffer b; b=a;
So buffer copy must allocates BufferPrivate.

Change-Id: Ic06227005204a24997b053a88cc48069bfd9c105
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/3759
Reviewed-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
TransportSocket, TransportServer: Fix thread-safeness.

Idea: TransportSocket destructor does not delete
the TransportSocketPrivate but call its destroy
method which takes care of destruction, asynchronously
if needed.

TransportSocketLibevent safe destruction is ensured by
posting delete request to the network thread, and
then delaying it until all asynchronous or potentially
reentrent (invoking callbacks) operations are finished.
Such operations are tracked by a simple atomic.

Change-Id: Ie7a8cb054616e1abc613ce2863bbd44e66b1a682

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
TransportSocketPrivate::waitForId: Fix.

Previous code was cond_waiting only once. But the cond_wait can be
triggered by a different message. So retry until the end of timeout.

Specifying a <0 timeout will check once, so for it to work the message
must already be there.

Change-Id: I1c012e26b9d56f0b362ce6f6449e962826dd8e86

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Buffer,DataStream: Remove streambuf logic from Buffer.

Currently, buffer holds the cursor, which is annoying: reading twice
the same buffer requires a reset.
So:
Split DataStream into IDataStream and ODataStream.
ODataStream just uses a Buffer, IDataStream goes through a BufferReader
which holds the cursor.

User-visible change:
DataStream is gone! Use IDataStream or ODataStream.

Adapt everywhere.

Change-Id: I60875942804eb488e4628e6d62edffd9295fe8d5
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/2946
Reviewed-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Events: Handle object destruction.

When an object is destroyed we need to disconnect  the events it
is linked to.
So also store subscribers in the target object, and properly remove
Subscribers from all structures in destructor.

Test it.

Change-Id: I9fc70b526ffe8c768c38d607a8243685f46518e7

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Events: Expose subscribers and implement signal-slot connect.

At this point object destruction is not handled.

Declare Subscriber in metaevent.hpp.
Extend it to store a functor or a pair (object, methodId).
Store the linkId in it.
Provide a subscribers() copy accessor in MetaEvent.
Adapt connect() backend to take a subscriber as argument.
New trivial connect(object*, methodid).

data.author: dmerejkowsky
data.message:
Port to android

* Add a special source file for process related functions
* Add a option to use std::queue instead of boost::lockfree
  (on by default for android, false by default eleswhere)

Non implemented functions:

  * qi::os::spawnvp
  * qi::os::spawnlp

(not sure why you'd want to use that on your phone ...)

  * qi::os::gethostname
  * qi::os::hostIPAddrs

(Use the Java API to do that instead)

 * Most of qi::path functions will not return usable results,
   but you should use the Java API for finding your resource
   files and so on...

Also, libqi will be dynamic or static depending on
BUILD_SHARED_LIBS, but dynamic by default also on windows

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Events: Implement remote connect/disconnect.

Three new messages: register, unregister (client->server)
and emit (server->client).

	* libqimessaging/qimessaging/message.hpp: Declare our new
	message types.
	* libqimessaging/src/remoteobject.cpp,
	* libqimessaging/src/remoteobject_p.hpp: Bounce connect and
	disconnect to the other side.
	* libqimessaging/src/server.cpp: Store a per-connection
	per-service (remoteid->localid) map. Handle register and
	deregister events. Deregister on client disconnect.

Change-Id: Iea83b27c85957b440024091a82b1f180944e0348
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/2755
Reviewed-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Events: Connect, local implementation.

Same layout as usual, a template connect frontend, that bounces
to xConnect which takes a Functor, that bounces to the virtual connect.

	* libqimessaging/qimessaging/object.hpp: Declare all that,
	and implement the template connect.
	* libqimessaging/src/object_p.hpp: Global UID counter.
	* libqimessaging/src/object.cpp (connect, xConnect, disconnect):
	Implement.

Change-Id: If90e101b0322fa1876a01113ec46d91d848fd2ff
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/2754
Reviewed-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.author: Matthieu Nottale
data.message:
Events: emit.

Interface is:
metaEmit() virtual backend (for remote implementation).
xMetaEmit() intermediate with event as string, and args in a Functor.
emitEvent template front.
trigger(): Just call local subscribers. We need to split it so that
a proxy may call local subscribers without reemiting the event.

	* libqimessaging/qimessaging/object.hpp (emitEvent, metaEmit,
	xMetaEmit, trigger): Declare.
	* libqimessaging/qimessaging/object.hxx.in,
	* libqimessaging/qimessaging/object.hxx: Implement emitEvent.
	* libqimessaging/src/object.cpp (metaEmit, xMetaEmit, trigger):
	Implement.
	* libqimessaging/src/remoteobject.cpp,
	* libqimessaging/src/remoteobject_p.hpp: Implement dummy remote
	trigger().

Change-Id: I14429c93acb00587dbaaa59839383cab5ec8f112
Reviewed-on: http://gerrit.aldebaran.lan:8080/2753
Reviewed-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>
Tested-by: mnottale <mnottale@aldebaran-robotics.com>

data.message:
Add QiCLI.

How to test:

Start a service directory. Then,

Usage:
$ qicli -h

Argv mode:
$ ./src/qi/lib/qimessaging/build-linux64/sdk/bin/qicli
      tcp://127.0.0.1:5555 service serviceDirectory

Interactive mode:
$ ./src/qi/lib/qimessaging/build-linux64/sdk/bin/qicli

data.author: vpaleologue
data.message:
core/libqi: new Project created out of cleaned ALProject code

Allows importation, exportation, representation and metadata management to
project directories, just like ALProject did, but without any dependency
to ALFile.

Project is a pimpl class and is currently implemented using boost. This
could also be done using Qt. Tests were adapted but are still incomplete:
we still need to check for locale support.
